The following reviews aim to give a rough guide to just a few of the many short film sites out there. Content and sites change; our reviewers' comments are what they found when they visited the sites during September 2000. All sites were tested on PCs and and macs and with both dial-up modem and broadband connections. We welcome your comments, and if you would like us to review your site, please email us at film.feedback@guardianunlimited.co.uk.

Reviews by Kate Stables, Sean Dodson, Emma Yates and Imogen Tilden.

Absolut Panushka
An online experimental animation festival that featured 32 films in 1998. Still live, still worth a look - in spite of all the films being about a very famous brand of Swedish vodka.

afilmcinado.net
A well-intentioned but sparsely stocked "alternative" site, which was concentrating largely on German shorts at our last glance. Horribly slow downloads (even with a broadband connection) meant that we couldn't gauge how trippy Irish thriller The Trip was intended to be. RealPlayer and QuickTime options are offered, but be prepared for a unhealthy wait between clicking and viewing.

always independent
A good selection of independent movies from minute-long shorts to full-length features. Also includes a classic film section that - if you have the patience - streams old black and whites like The Three Stooges' Brideless Groom and Chaplin's The Gold Rush. You'll need a Windows Media Player to see the majority of them (sorry, mac users).

AtomFilms
Probably the most famous and most visited short film site on the Web. Atom's comprehensive choice and popular content make it a good place to learn what you enjoy - and what you want to avoid - in the world of webfilm. Roam all over this vast and varied site, to sample work running from Oscar nominated shorts, through festival favourites and foreign films, to "extreme" interactive animations. To see more than featured picks requires registration as an Atom Insider, which is free and doesn't (to date) result in a tsunami of junk email. All streaming video formats are catered for. Gadget freaks can have shorts sent to their personal digital organizer or WAP phone, to stun the bus queue.

Bijou Cafe
Movie lovers with a taste for kitsch cinema will love this site - as long as they have access to a superfast connection. Bijou Cafe stream old feature-length movies from Peter Cushing and Christopher Lee in Horror Express to transvestite classic Glen or Glenda.

BinaryTheater
A cheerful American single page site with half a dozen titles, all under 15 minutes. Its raison d'être is to give free, unlimited distribution to the best work from US film schools. We'd guess that the cream of US film school shorts pour headlong onto higher-profile sites like Atom and IFilm, but if you have a RealVideo plugin, this is worth a quick look.

The Bit Screen
Convince yourself that the web is the next broadcast medium, by stopping in at The Bit Screen. Owner Nora Barry has a messianic interest in first run web-specific work, and this is the place to pick up on interactive artistic novelties like self-assembly webfilms. Look out for Random Shuffles - films programmed to reconfigure for each successive site visitor. Succulent animations were programmed when we visited, including Billy Blob's stylised satire Darwin Bug. Four works are featured every week, which can be viewed using Shockwave or RealPlayer, but there's no on-site archive


Camp Chaos
Cartoonist Bob Cesca's web HQ, and home to his set of energetic, taste-free Flash cartoon series, which are updated weekly. Lovers of American "extreme content" animation will fall giggling onto his topical spoofs, but we preferred Mafia series This Thing of Ours. Browse through Public Domain Theater, which marries cheesy black and white B-movie footage with parody voiceover, should you have the time. If you can't hear anything, check you've updated your Flash plugin.

Culturejam
Culturejam is that counter-culture curiosity, a site dedicated to streaming subversive media to the masses. A welcome shot of guerilla media is delivered in a single RealPlayer short film, highlighting the issue of the week. Sticking it to the military-industrial complex when we showed up was the mind-expander's manifesto Mother May I ? (Control My Own Consciousness). There's no film archive on site, so counter-media connoisseurs will need to demonstrate solidarity by regular attendance.


D.Film
Now grown up from its diminutive indie roots into a fully fledged festival and supporting website, D.film picks one film a month to showcase. Recent highlights include an excerpt from The Week Before, a beautiful, slow-moving silent movie about God in the seven days before he created the earth, and Mutate, by British director Jack Price. Each film offers you the option of downloading it or watching it via streaming QuickTime.


Director Unknown
Using a Dogme '95-style manifesto to create a "movie of the web", six young American film-makers have put together a fresh but flakey 12-episode RealPlayer thriller on this site. Each short episode was shot in a day by a member of the collective, and sometimes - inevitably - it shows. Watch their Lynchian streamed video in episode order, using a broadband connection if at all possible.

Evan Mather
The delightful and diverse offerings of prolific short film-maker Evan Mather, packed into a single page site, both Mac and PC-friendly. He made his name with surreal Star Wars parodies like Les Pantless Menace, one of a series of lo-tech spoofs stuffed with plastic figurines and disco soundtracks. If these crowd-pleasers leave you cold, try out his funky, rough-edged animations, such as Fansom The Lizard. An excellent antidote to the plague of one-joke Flash cartoons that friends insist on cramming into your email inbox with.


Flash Film Festival
The showcase site for New York's July 2000 Flash Film Festival, which "honoured the best motion graphics and animation on earth". Although the festival has been and gone, you can still roam through the 10 categories (including design, 3D, interactivity, cartoons), and check out the five finalists. The games section is particularly good fun - we liked Assassinate A Celebrity and Chicken Killer. But the navigation can be confusing and, when we looked, some of the pages weren't accessible. Overall the site is well designed and good fun though.

Get Out There
Fresh, unvarnished first-time film-making is BT's site's selling-point. When we visited, we found a choice of 116 lively QuickTime film shorts and animations, some more highly-polished than others. Since films automatically gather points when they are visited - rather than voted for - you may find the Top 10 charts longer on novelty than quality. Jewels like Chris Titchborne's Tommy Grimbald or couch potato cautionary tale Horsehair can be found lower down the listings, with a bit of digging. We liked the Least Popular Films chart option, with its very British appeal for lovers of lame-dog cinema.

hahabonk
Holy arse-kicking ecclesiasticals! Undisputed star of this likeably laddish British comedy site is the animated series The Cloth, which owes more to the comic book than the Good Book. We also liked Sickboys Pocket Cinema for animated 30-second versions of movie classics, all sicker than Linda Blair on a cross-channel ferry. You'll need RealPlayer and Flash plugins to access the site, and patience for the excruciatingly slow downloads on normal modems.

Heavy.com
Superfunky, laid-back site that gives you the choice of "slim" or "fat" modem speeds before unleashing its hip hop-tinged content on yo' ass. Predominantly music and TV-based, there's a wonderful pastiche of Behind the Music called Behind the Music That Sucks, deriding superstars such as Barbra Streisand and Billy Joel. You can get seriously distracted in the 'Contagious' section ("it's probably in your inbox already"), which is full of those annoying 20-second clips of disgruntled office workers going ape. Too chilled out for any type of mission statement, the site works on a pin-and-blindfold style of navigation.


Hollywood Shorts
Aims to provide emerging directors, writers, and producers the means of showing their short films and videos. Three or four films are showcased on the site each month, as well as screened at a cinema in Los Angeles. It's the closest to cinema film yet: each short lasts up to 40 minutes, but navigation is simple and a choice of modem speed is available for each film. Painful indeed for those of us without broadband access, but worth paying attention to in the future.


HotWired: Animation Express
We haven't been so excited by a rectangular window since watching Playschool. Look into this site to catch a fine selection of glossy animation in vast, glitch-free video windows. Pick anything you fancy off the front-page carousel - it's all pretty damn good frankly. We were taken with arty fare like The Last Hula Doll, as well as the enjoyably perverse Sex Slave Series , whose plotlines do indeed "mesh like a well-oiled orgy". There is big name content too, from Joe Corrao and Pixar Studios. Flash, Shockwave and QuickTime plugins required, all of which are available onsite.

Hypnotic
Seasoned webfilm seekers may remember this site as Reelshort, before its acquisition by Universal Pictures. Now reborn as 'new media film studio' Hypnotic, the site boasts a glossy new look and a significantly sharper range of films. All the usual hype-dodging rules still apply however - try and avoid ballyhooed spoofs (like The Sick Sense) and have a rummage in the channels. We approved thoroughly of Hypnotic's line in bizarre or experimental work such as Nude Descending and Crawley. Oh, and don't forget to sample their popular and wonderfully offensive episodic series Rick and Steve, the Happiest Gay Couple In All the World .

Icebox
Another Flash animation site that boasts that this is independent film-making with "no rules, no filters, no studio executives." And while its Hidden Celebrity Webcam is an admirable spoof, Icebox too often ladles up a series of episodic shorts that all can suffer from being more than a little juvenile. Still, the cartoons are well drawn and the site is admirably organised.

ifilm
Claims, not unjustifiably, to be the best place for internet film. ifilm certainly is one of the best starting points for newcomers, part portal - offering links to other webfilms and sites - and part independent - commissioning and screening shorts of its own. Films are divided thematically, the running time is listed for each, and most offer the choice of viewing media. The navigation is clear and easy and user review options complete an impressively rounded picture.


JibJab
This New York-based Flash cartoon site was only established in November 1999, but has already won a host of industry awards. Dedicated to "producing original entertainment for online channels", the Spiridelli brothers have created a host of animated characters such as Nasty Santa, Hoola Boy and the farting waffle. Although some of the humour is a tad adolescent, the Interactive Rapping President is a wonder to behold. mac and pc users both should have no problems.

Mediatrip
Sharp and successful spoofs have been the engine behind the growth of this quickwitted American entertainment site. Home of web parody hits like audience-charmer George Lucas in Love, MediaTrip also turns up occasional gems in other genres: award-winning fantasy Sentinelle hooked our interest when we ploughed through the Top 10 on your behalf. Sophisticates shouldn't miss Lil' Pimp, the freckle-faced tot who puts the 'ho in "ho-ho-ho".

The New Venue
Set up in 1996 by Jason Wishnow, the "enfant terrible of digital film", this was the first site dedicated to movies made expressly for the internet. It's for digital film-makers as much as desktop film viewers: one film is highlighted as the weekly feature, with an extensive back archive, and the Flick Tips section is a must for wannabe film-makers giving detailed advice on how to make your own digital film. If you've been paying attention, you can submit your own work for consideration. A great starting point to the whole medium; this site won't make you feel completely overwhelmed.

Pitch TV
A New York-based site that collects poetic animations and short films mostly from southern Europe and latin America. Each short is either dubbed or subtitled and the films are shown in a pop-up box courtesy of Macromedia Flash. There is a notable world movie e-zine to accompany the films. But it is the shorts that are of most interest here. They are, quite literally, poetry in motion.

The Quickie
Small but perfectly formed animation site. Terming itself "one of the internet's premiere cartoon animation sites", the navigation is simple, and the site's sense of humour is evident on every page. Don't miss the Star Wars - Episode 9, a prize winner in the World Entertainment Animation animated comedy / parody category. Han Solo has become a Travis Bickle-type figure, while Luke uses the force to move papers from the in to the out tray at work in the Jedi corporation. mac and pc-friendly.

Reel Screen
reelscreen sensibly offer just five "highest rated" and "new film" picks apiece on the film page of this smart British site. Which steered us straight to the best of their holdings, studded with goodies like feverish festival fave Nite Owl, and Jester, Nick Herbert's accomplished medieval animation. We suggest you stick to the chart path, unless you have the urge, the time and the stamina to work through their diverse archive, whose film listings can be unhelpfully bald.

ShortFest
Those serious about shorts should bookmark this ingenious American site, which employs a festival format with seasonal changes of programme. ShortFest is made up of five thoughtful strands of US and international short film programming, each themed and guest-curated by an industry specialist. When we checked in, Moira Griffin's Telling Tales strand had gems such as Jim Trainor's pencil scrawled picaresque, Bats. Some films can run as long as 25-40 minutes, so use the programme notes to plan your viewing. Currently only available in QuickTime and RealPlayer.

sputnik7
Drop-dead cool US entertainment site and haven for lovers of Japanese "anime" film. Those happy few with broadband and unmetered access can find a continuous programme of short films and full length anime features such as Orguss 02, on video channel 7.04. The rest of us steer our way to the modish video-on-demand choices, which run in RealPlayer or Windows Media Player. If you wish to browse the archives, you'll need to register as a site user.

The Surrey Stick Figure Theatre of Death
An oldie but goldie, which dates from the web's prelapsarian period but is still commanding a devoted following for its weekly releases. David Thorpe's sly stick-figure massacres are 10-second masterpieces of black humour and comic timing. Thumb through the vast archive to find Theatre of Death classics like The Surrealist and Hamlet, or sample cinema spoofs like Pulp Sticktion. Severed-head-and-shoulders above similar sites, in our opinion.

Switch2.net
A good-looking UK general entertainment site, with a grabby come-hither animated interface. SHORTS, their film channel, turns out to be fewer than 10 - albeit classy - choices of film. Australian director Monica Pellizari's quirky Just Desserts, and a winning selection from the Rushes Soho Shorts Festival 2000 were on offer when we visited. For such a user-friendly site, the lack of film timings and the provision of matchbook-sized viewing windows are an unnecessary irritant.


Undergroundfilm.com
Not as alternative as its name might suggest. Still, it offers up a well-chosen archive of 180 independent shorts (mostly American), with a fair selection of artistic film, plus one bizarre experimental animated series, the macabre Braingirl. Dive straight into the handful of rotating Editor's Film Picks on the home page, to avoid the fiddly list-based navigation system. We hit lucky with Flucht, an atmospheric monochrome thriller following one man and his paranoia around a small German town. QuickTime 4 only here, but the site's spacious video windows and crisp images may well be worth the download time to acquire it.

Urban Desires
Primarily an online magazine, this is a stylish site that also showcases the work of new directors. There is good supplementary material including interviews with the directors and an archive of previously shown work. It looks great, but the almost total lack of comprehensive navigation makes it a frustrating experience.

Urban Entertainment
This hip, black-themed entertainment site has a breakout hit on its hands in animated blaxploitation spoof series Undercover Brother. Though the compact short film section has its moments - try Charles Stone's goofy True for size - we found that animated series like the raucous Pookie Poo were the real finds. Graphic-novel enthusiasts will also want to check out moody adult animated thriller The Contract. Gratifyingly fast daytime downloads, provided you've got Flash or RealPlayer.

It is widely acknowledged that Ronnie Irani is in the best form of his career with both bat and ball. Certainly Glamorgan will testify to that - and not because of this match.

In June Cardiff was the scene of a nine-hour, career-best 168 not out. On this occasion he was not so productive, falling five short of his century, but he nevertheless produced an innings of immense value to guide his county away from a precipice.

Paul Grayson, Paul Prichard and Will Jefferson, the 20-year-old debutant, had departed within the opening five overs with only 13 on the board when a purposeful Irani strode out to join Stuart Law.

He announced his arrival by finding the boundary with his first three scoring strokes and, together with the Australian, was to prise the initiative away from the Welsh county as quickly as they had seized it.

Three successive fours by Law raised the 50 in the 12th over and the total moved into three figures at the rate of just under five an over. By then Irani had become more passive and was content to watch Law dictate with some effortless driving off the front foot.

Law looked in such control that it came as something of a surprise when, driving on the up, he dispatched Robert Croft to mid-on having scored 70 in 92 deliveries, 10 of which were boundaries.

Irani's response was to drive Croft straight for six to complete his half-century and he continued to ease the ball into the gaps until he was given out lbw when pushing forward to the slow left-armer Dean Kosker. Thereafter James Foster, another 20-year-old debutant, showed fine composure to score 52 before the return of Steve Watkin breached his forward push.

British ministers demanded action from their French counterparts today after thousands of holiday makers and hauliers were left stranded by the French fishermen's blockade of Channel ports.

Traffic eventually started moving again by mid-afternoon after fishermen called off their action and the blockaded French ports reopened. The stalemate ended after the Paris government agreed to reduce the price of fuel.

Deputy prime minister John Prescott told the French government that the impact of the industrial action was "unacceptable" and British hauliers demanded compensation for the huge disruption to cross-Channel travel. The cost to British industry of the protest against high French fuel prices was estimated at £5m, in addition to the inconvenience caused to British holiday makers left queuing for hours to get home from France. Earlier there were angry scenes at the Channel tunnel's Calais terminal as Britons tried to clear the barricades.

Travel companies warned it would be hours before services returned to normal, while police said jams on the M20 in Kent on the way to Dover were likely to continue.

In the port of Le Havre, more than 740 Portsmouth-bound passengers had to spend Wednesday night and Thursday morning aboard a P&O vessel, the Pride of Le Havre, after fishermen, who started their blockade early, prevented the ship from leaving. The vessel was finally able to sail from Le Havre early this afternoon and was due to dock at Portsmouth tonight.

Huge queues of lorries had built up outside Dover and at the ports hit by the dispute - Calais, Cherbourg, Dunkirk, Le Havre and St Malo.

Ferry companies put on extra services to French and Belgian ports unaffected by the dispute. Channel Tunnel shuttle train services between Folkestone and Calais were running, but passengers had trouble getting through the protesters to reach the trains.

The UK ports hit by the effect of the blockades in France were Dover, Portsmouth, Plymouth and Poole. Ferry companies P&O Stena Line, SeaFrance, Norfolk Line, Brittany Ferries, and P&O Portsmouth were all affected.

In a letter to French transport minister Jean-Claude Gayssot today, Mr Prescott said the action of protesting fishermen was contrary to EU legislation.

He went on: "The action is unacceptable to us. Stranded road hauliers on both sides of the Channel stand to lose millions of pounds.

"The actions of the protesters are contrary to EU legislation on the free movement of goods and will badly tarnish the image of France in Britain."

Simon Murphy, the Labour leader in the European parliament, wrote to EU transport commission Loyola de Palacio demanding compensation for UK holiday makers caught up in the dispute.

Mr Murphy said: "Back in 1997, the European court ruled that countries must prevent such obstructions to trade or they would be fined. But the French government still allows them to go on.

"This is no way to run a modern Europe which depends on the free trade and free movement of people."

The consolidation spree within ITV is spurring news service ITN and digital terrestrial platform ONdigital's flotation plans.

Both are companies owned by key network players. Executives at Granada Media and Carlton Communications, the main shareholders in both companies, are poised to draw up initial public offering options. ONdigital is at the most advanced stage towards a stock market listing.

ONdigital is trailing rival BSkyB and the tussle for control of ITV between its joint owners has prevented a flotation that would boost funding for its expansion plans. However, Granada's £1.75bn deal for United News & Media's TV franchises has re-opened the possibility of an IPO.

The plans are complicated by Granada's ownership of the HTV franchise, which it must sell to satisfy regulators following the United acquisition. Granada chairman Charles Allen is aware of counterpart Michael Green's interest in HTV and could upset negotiations by selling the franchise to another party.

An ITN flotation is still at the early stages of development, as a lot hinges on what Granada does with its holding in the company. No company can hold more than 20% of the news service, which is co-owned by Granada, Carlton, Reuters, the Daily Mail & General Trust and United. It means Granada has to dispose of the stake it inherited from United or sell the shares to the public.

The proceeds from an ITN public offering would be used to fund the company's internet ambitions and boost its international services. However, it is possible that the sale of Granada's stake will provide enough money to finance its plans. Analysts put ITN's full IPO value at between £200m and £300m.

Merill Lynch analyst Neil Blackley said: "The money available from the Granada stake is not primary money, so it would probably have to be made available through an IPO. In terms of the whole organisation, though, ITN is a perfectly viable IPO and an excellent company."

On August 30, Granada's share price fell 5.25p to 670.75p, with Carlton climbing 26p to 726p.

ITV fired an agressive salvo in the soap opera ratings war yesterday with the announcement of a rival to EastEnders and a revival of Crossroads. Giving the nation a new generation of gay fathers, power-bitches and angst-ridden teenagers to idolise, ITV said it would "stuff the BBC" in the popular drama battleground.

Trafalgar Road, a tea time series based on a group of friendly-but-flawed families, is a high risk attempt to create the network's first London-based soap - the heartland dominated by the BBC's ratings winner, EastEnders.

At the same time, Crossroads has shed the shaky sets and dodgy scripts of its 70s incarnation in a makeover promoted by Lord Alli, director of production at Carlton, part of a drive to revive ITV's afternoon schedule.

Both series, costing £40,000 an episode, will run for at least a year, five days a week.

They are among the biggest risks taken by ITV's director of programmes, David Liddiment, since he took over in 1997.

Like Lord Alli's new Labour party, new Crossroads will bear only a passing resemblance to the original.

While there is a part for Jane Rossington, the actress who opened the first episode in 1964 with the immortal lines "Crossroads motel, can I help you?", there is no room for the idiot savant of the original series, Benny Hawkins. Producers have decided that his simple but lovable character is not suitable for a 21st century audience.

Rossington's character, Jill Chance, will stage a dramatic return from the West Country to claim a stake in the business. A power battle ensues with new owner Kate Russell, who may be played by one half of the Dempsey and Makepeace cop show duo, Glynis Barber. There will be a new, glamorous receptionist to replace Miss Diane, and a hunky young porter to complete the sexier line-up.

Steve Hewlett, Carlton's director of programmes, said the remake would not suffer from the wobbly sets and incredible storylines that plagued the later stages of the original show. "It won't have any of those defects. This has fantastic storylines and very high production values."

Old fans would recognise some elements. Kathy Staff, who played the gossipy cleaner and kitchen worker, Doris Luke, is earmarked for a comeback. But new viewers would not suffer from a lack of background knowledge. "While it is not afraid of its roots, it will work as a new drama in its own right," Mr Hewlett said.

Trafalgar Road, made by United Productions, will fill the tea time slot vacated by Home and Away, poached by Channel 5. It is described as less gritty and depressing than EastEnders: "It's deeply moral, sweet and funny, but has a strong thriller element," said the show's executive producer, Damien Timmer.

It is based around the Harper, Wells, Drake and Mills families: Mike Drake is a middle aged father struggling with his homosexuality, just as his 16-year-old son Tim is going through his own teenage rite of passage with Frankie Mills, the girl next door.

Further dramatic tension is provided by a handsome young footballer, Sam Hayden: the 17-year-old must choose between his dream of a dazzling career with Charlton Athletic, where he is on the youth team, and bringing up his baby brother and young sister following the death of his parents.

Mr Liddiment said the commissions were substantial investments in UK drama. "Soaps play an important role in connecting channels with their audience.

"In a multi-channel age, I believe their ability to create 'appointments to view' in the schedule will be even more crucial."

Dud suds: Soaps that failed

Eldorado
Launched in 1992 by the team that created EastEnders, it soon fell victim to tabloid vilification. It was launched too quickly and with little imagination, less investment. Not even the southern Spain location could save it.

Albion Market
ITV's Manchester answer to EastEnders suffered from bizarre scheduling - Friday to Sunday. Patchy commitment from some ITV regions signed its death warrant.

Families
Short-lived daily offering from Granada. David Liddiment, ITV director of programmes, then based at the Manchester broadcaster, learned many lessons from its failure, including the key "keep it simple" premise. Families was partly based in Sydney, and the global storylines were just too far-fetched.

London Bridge
It has to be hoped that Carlton's first attempt at a soap is not replicated in Crossroads. The London-based drama never took off outside the capital, and was axed in 1996, a year after its launch.

Family Affairs
Channel 5's attempt at a daily soap suffered from the Crossroads curse of acting even more wooden than the sets. Mass cull of main characters aimed to save it. Still on the air, but some would question why.

They are fresh faced twenty-somethings who wear combat trousers to work and dream about making a fast buck while burning vast sums of someone else's venture capital.

At least that is what we thought dot.com entrepreneurs were supposed to be.

New research from KPMG Consulting suggests that the identikit "e-business leader" is actually a far more sober-suited type. Typically aged 38, he often works seven days a week, has little time for a social life and is more likely to be found travelling economy class on a budget airline than the business class of a longer established carrier.

And nine out of 10 dot.com directors say they would wear a traditional suit to an important meeting because casual dress was "inappropriate".

The report, E-Business Leaders Survey 2000, paints dot.com directors in a far more flattering light than the publicity many in cyberspace have attracted after high-profile failures by the likes of Boo.com.

"Most people think that dot.coms are run by young graduates, who make loads of money in a short space of time," said Alan Buckle, chief executive of KPMG Consulting UK. "The dot.com leaders we surveyed work hard and are extremely dedicated - they are not kids, playing at business and hoping to make a fast buck.

"The research shows that there really is no short cut to success in the new economy. Just like a traditional business, a net venture will only thrive thanks to the hard work and business sense of its people.

"But there are critical differences in how dot.com leaders work that are increasingly likely to spread to the rest of the UK plc - particularly the focus on keeping costs to a minimum and the changing work patterns that reflect the 24/7 culture of the internet world."

KPMG interviewed 101 executives and found several differences between dot.com and traditional company working patterns. The biggest gap is in the median annual company turnover of the two groups: for traditional businesses it was £860m, for internet firms just £750,000.

Despite the gap both groups worked more than 56 hours a week on average. Directors of internet firms are twice as likely as traditional directors to work 71 hours per week and 40% are still in the office after 8pm.

More than a third said they have little time to relax or socialise and when they do take time out to read a book almost half read business books rather than fiction. On average dot.com directors take less than half of their annual holiday entitlement.

Internet directors are less likely to have degrees or backgrounds in finance but more have had private educations and come from marketing backgrounds.

The average age of the two groups of directors was much closer than researchers expected. Although 10 times as many dot.com directors were under 30 than those in traditional businesses, the average age of executives at new economy firms was an older than expected 38. The average age of old economy business leaders was 46.

What motivates each group also threw up some interesting results. Dot.com directors cited the chance to grow a business from scratch, working in a young, dynamic environment and stock options as the three biggest motivating factors. Old economy directors say they are turned on most by stock options and high salaries.

When it comes to dressing for work, 82% of dot.com executives favour permanent dress down days but nine out of 10 will put on a suit for an important business meeting. Eight out of 10 old economy bosses wear suits every day.

Nearly half of all executives plan to retire by the time they are 60 but almost 15% of e-business leaders love work so much they do not plan to hang over the reigns until they are 70.

August 25 2000: Dyke used the MacTaggart Lecture, the keynote speech at the Guardian Edinburgh international television festival, to outline a future vision for the BBC based on the principle of "universality" - making all the corporation's publicly funded services available in all homes. He added that in the digital era the BBC's single most important role will be to make "great British programmes".

He said universality meant the BBC will limit itself to seven licence fee-funded TV services on five channels - the maximum that could fit on the BBC's digital terrestrial multiplex and be available free to all digital TV viewers.

The services, Dyke said, would include a BBC1 focused on delivering "greater impact", but without banishing all current affairs, documentaries, religion and arts. Dyke also announced that the BBC planned to move its 9pm news to 10pm from 2001.

BBC2, he added, would take some shows from BBC1 and become the channel for "intelligent specialist factual", leisure and lifestyle, "thoughtful analysis, creatively ambitious drama and comedy, and specialist sports".

But Dyke said this gradual transformation would take years, maybe until after analogue switch-off - estimated to take place towards the end of the decade. He added that BBC1 and BBC2 would continue to be aimed at analogue viewers, who are expected to make up the majority of TV homes until at least 2003.

BBC Choice would be transformed into youth-oriented service BBC3; while BBC Knowledge was to become BBC4, "a mixture of Radios 3 and 4 on television". The other services would be News 24 and two children's services, aimed at pre-school and six to 13-year-olds, which will go out on BBC3 and 4 during the daytime.

Dyke also announced that the BBC would be spending an extra £480m on programmes and services within two years - a 30% increase in real terms over three years. More than half the extra money will be spent on BBC1 and 2, with BBC3 and 4 having a combined budget of £130m and the Nations and Regions getting an extra £50m.

August 7: BBC lobbying was reported to have persuaded the government not to abolish the board of governors. But the BBC governors are expected to have their powers curtailed and be made to report to a single independent regulator that will be created to oversee the broadcasting industry.

August 6: The Sunday Times reported that Greg Dyke was planning to use his MacTaggart speech at the Edinburgh TV festival to unveil plans to reposition BBC Choice and BBC Knowledge as BBC3 and BBC4. The newspaper reported that BBC3 would be relaunched in April 2001 as a youth channel with a £92m annual budget. BBC4, which is to be repositioned as a high-brow arts, science and politics channel, is expected to have a £50m budget. Dyke was said to have discussed his plans with the BBC governors during their monthly meeting in July and to have described BBC4 as a "virtual Tate Modern".

July 13: In his first appearance before the Commons media select committee as director-general, Dyke told MPs that the BBC needed to adapt to a digital multi-channel TV environment. He said BBC1 would largely become an entertainment channel, while assuring the committee that there would always be a place for current affairs. BBC2 would carry more serious output, while BBC Choice would become youth and comedy channel BBC3. BBC Knowledge would evolve into BBC4 - an arts and culture channel.

July 12: Dyke failed in his bid to lure friend and former LWT colleague lord Melvyn Bragg to the BBC. Lord Bragg signed a lucrative four-year contract to remain LWT controller of arts and features.

July 10: It was announced that up to 1,100 BBC jobs were to go as part of Dyke's restructuring of the organisation. Most of the job losses and 70% of accompanying savings were to come from support areas - including human resources, marketing and publicity, strategy and finance - and management, with around 200 posts expected to be axed from the resources division.

The cuts form part of measures expected to produce savings of £750m over the next six years, as the BBC strives to meet Dyke's target of increasing the proportion of licence fee revenue it spends on programming and services from 76% to 85%.

Dyke also unveiled further details of the new BBC corporate structure he would be introducing, including four new TV genre commissioners for entertainment, drama, factual and arts programming, who would work with the channel controllers.

Within the factual and learning production division, 10 department heads were asked to compete for three new posts: head of documentaries and investigations, leisure and factual programming and specialist factual. A new head of religion and ethics post was also created within the division.

Factual and learning was asked to work with BBC News to create a business programming department.

The former drama and entertainment department management teams were to be merged and streamlined within the new drama, entertainment and children's production division, under Alan Yentob, who would also oversee a new innovative unit, Fictionlab.

BBC Radio, headed by Jenny Abramsky, was renamed Radio & Music.

June 21: Dyke announced a further £15m in funding for BBC1 and BBC2 - to come from efficiency savings - as the BBC unveiled its 1999-2000 annual report. In the face of criticism from the BBC governors that the average quality of BBC1 shows "was still not good enough", Dyke promised a "fundamental change" in the channel's performance. But he skirted around a question about whether BBC1 controller Peter Salmon was to blame for the channel's poor showing.

The annual report also revealed that Dyke's predecessor, Sir John Birt, received a termination payment of £328,400 for retiring early.

June 15: The BBC won back live rights to the FA Cup final from ITV. The corporation also secured live rights to England's home football internationals, as part of a £400m three-year deal with BSkyB.

However, Dyke was forced to back-track on accusations of skulduggery by ITV and the Premiership in the earlier deal to wrest Match of the Day football highlights away from the BBC. Match of the Day will be revived for a handful of weekends each year to cover the FA Cup.

June 14: Dyke, who arrived at the BBC promising to reverse the loss of key sports rights, suffered the biggest reversal of his tenure to date when ITV snatched Premiership highlights, effectively signalling the death-knell for Saturday night BBC1 institution Match of the Day. The BBC lost out despite doubling what it paid for the previous highlights deal - to £120m over three years. Dyke misjudged how much ITV wanted the rights; the commercial broadcaster bid £183m.

June 12: In the first public indication of a major shift in the BBC's strategic thinking, director of television Mark Thompson announced plans to move from the mixed schedules offered by BBC1 and BBC2 to genre-based channels. In a speech at the Banff TV festival in Canada, which was drafted in close consultation with Dyke, he said there would be "no sacred cows" in a review of how the BBC should adapt its TV output for the digital multi-channel era. Thompson added that genre-based channels would allow the BBC to extend, rather than dilute, its public service remit.

But the speech aroused immediate fears that the BBC was planning to dumb down its TV output and turn BBC1 into an entertainment service, shifting news and serious documentaries and current affairs to BBC2.

On the same day, it was announced that BBC director of public policy Patricia Hodgson was leaving the corporation to become Independent Television Commission chief executive. Hodgson was regarded as one of Sir John Birt's most trusted lieutenants, and her role had already been diminished under Dyke.

June 5: ITV controller of children's and youth Nigel Pickard, who worked for Dyke at TVS in the 80s, was poached to become BBC controller of children's programmes.

May 20: Grandstand, the BBC's flagship Saturday afternoon sports programme, was cancelled because of a lack of decent events to show. The 42-year-old institution, which had previously only come off air during annual holiday periods and the funeral of Diana, princess of Wales, was the victim of the BBC's loss of sports rights.

May 13: Dyke risked sparking a political row with the appointment of former Independent editor Andrew Marr as the BBC's political editor. Marr, who is regarded as left-leaning, was recruited by Dyke and head of news Tony Hall to replace Robin Oakley. Oakley, a former Times political editor with Conservative sympathies, was persuaded to retire a year early to make way for Marr.

May 10: In a further cost-cutting measure, BBC department heads received a memo from Dyke informing them that in future croissants would not be served at breakfast meetings.

May 2: A shuttle bus service was introduced to ferry staff between Broadcasting House in central London and Television Centre 'out west'. The move formed part of a Dyke-inspired clampdown on taxi costs.

April 7: Dyke pledged to increase the proportion of BBC employees from ethnic minorities to 10%, and double the number of managers from ethnic backgrounds by 2003, in a speech at the race in the media awards dinner. He said people from ethnic minorities made up 8% of the BBC workforce, but only 2% of managers.

April 3: Unveiling his strategic vision for "One BBC", Dyke promised to spend at least an extra £100m on programming and services in the coming year.

He announced plans for a flatter management structure, with an 18-strong executive committee at its centre.

Dyke also set a target of reducing the proportion of licence fee income spent on running the BBC from 24% to 15% over the next five years - in order to invest more in programming.

He said this would free up £200m a year to spend on programmes and help meet the government's savings target of £1.2bn over the next seven years. Dyke indicated that drama and entertainment would be top of the list for extra funding, but said neglected areas, such as local radio, would also benefit.

Dyke said he wanted to bring programme-makers closer to the centre of decision-making - 10 out of the 18 executive committee members would be responsible for production or broadcasting, compared with four in the previous senior executive forum.

As part of the management reorganisation, the much-maligned, Birt-inspired division between the BBC's broadcasting and production operations was abolished, along with the independent commissioning group. Four programming divisions were created: drama, entertainment & children, factual and learning, sport & news - along with a new media division to develop interactive TV and online operations.

In sport, children's and education, commissioning and programme-making were reintegrated. All in-house producers were to be offered output guarantees and longer term commissions. And the BBC internal market was to be simplified, with the number of business units cut from 190 to 50.

In radio, Abramsky was given responsibility for Radio 5 Live and music production - from the News and Production directorates, respectively.

March 8: The BBC saw off Kelvin MacKenzie's TalkSport to retain radio rights to England's home cricket Tests, in a bid orchestrated by Dyke. The BBC was said to have paid about £2m for the five-year deal.

March 2: Helen Boaden was appointed Radio 4 controller, replacing James Boyle.

February 21: Chris Smith announced a BBC funding settlement that gave it a rise in licence fee income equivalent to £200m a year over the next seven years. As a result, the licence fee for 2000-2001 would rise by 1.5% above inflation from April 1 - to £104.

While offering the BBC more money, Smith neatly side-stepped the £24 digital licence fee proposed by the Davies committee, which had been so roundly condemned by commercial rivals as a "digital poll tax".

But the increase he offered was well below the extra £3bn the BBC had asked for to see it through to the end of the existing licence fee charter period in April 2007. Describing his proposals as "tough love", Smith ordered the BBC to find a further £1.1bn in funding from "self-help" measures, including efficiency savings and increased commercial income.

Smith also announced plans to reform the BBC's self-governing status. The role of the board of governors was to be reviewed, along with the corporation's finances and fair trading commitments and the public service justification for new digital services such as News 24. He also confirmed a number of new licence fee concessions, including half-price fees for the blind and a free licence for the over-75s.

February 6: Dyke sanctioned the launch of a dedicated BBC online sports website. On the same day, BSkyB snatched the rights to cover the Bafta film awards ceremony from the corporation.

February 1: On his first official day in charge of the BBC, Dyke told an audience of 450 senior staff gathered at Television Centre to stop moaning or leave. He pledged to put programmes first and free up money to spend on them, starting with a £10m reduction in the cost of hiring management consultants.

His second main aim was to improve the BBC's internal culture. Dyke praised his predecessor Sir John's achievements, especially the launch of BBC Online.

January 31:Sir John's last day as director-general.

January 20: Dyke bowed to mounting pressure from critics and sold his £6m holding in Granada - pre-empting a meeting with the BBC governors, after which he could have been ordered to sell the stake. In a statement, Dyke said he had decided to sell the shares to prevent his early days as director-general from being dominated by controversy.

January 16: It emerged that the BBC governors had given Dyke until the end of April - two months after taking over as director-general - to sell his Granada shares - valued at about £6m. The disclosure prompted howls of protest about a possible conflict of interest. Dyke acquired the equity stake when Granada took over LWT.

January 1: Sir John became a lord, courtesy of the new year's honours list. On the same day, the BBC announced that he would be stepping down two months earlier than planned, at the end of January, giving credence to the theory that the life peerage formed part of a trade-off to prize his hands off the BBC tiller.

November 18 1999: In his first major public speech after being appointed director-general, Dyke pledged to place education at the heart of his strategy.

November 1 1999: Dyke joined the BBC as director-general designate, working alongside Sir John in a handover period due to last until the end of March 2000. The pair were to share adjoining offices.

Dyke announced immediately that he would be overseeing a review of the relationship between the Broadcast directorate and other BBC divisions, including Production and the corporate centre.

BBC observers took this as an indication that he intended to dismantle the corporate structure put in place by Sir John. The review was to take in TV commissioning, the four national radio services, new digital TV channels and BBC Online. Dyke would also take over direct control of Broadcast when chief executive Will Wyatt retired at the end of the year.

October 1 1999: Dyke resigned from the board of Manchester United.

August 29 1999: BBC1 controller Peter Salmon told the Guardian Edinburgh International TV Festival that he would be asking Dyke for an extra £100m in his annual budget to combat falling ratings. Salmon had faced mounting criticism because of falling ratings and the alleged dumbing down of BBC1 output.

August 19 1999: Dyke sold his remaining Pearson shares, netting £800,000.

August 5 1999: A government-appointed committee chaired by leading economist Gavyn Davies recommended that the BBC's future funding needs be met by introducing a digital licence fee. The Davies committee's report suggested the additional licence fee be levied from people with access to digital TV services. It would initially be set at £24 from April 2000, but then fall as the uptake of digital services grew - to £12 by 2006.

The Davies report estimated that this measure, along with efficiency savings, the privatisation of BBC Resources and sale of a 49% stake in BBC Worldwide, would net the corporation an extra £150-200m a year over this period.

The committee recommended that advertising, subscription or sponsorship should not be introduced to the BBC's core services. They also said the BBC's accounts should more transparent and open to greater scrutiny by the Office of Fair Trading and National Audit Office, and that the licence fee discount for blind people should be increased to 50%.

The Davies report's digital licence fee recommendation was criticised by Sir John for not providing sufficient money to meet the corporation's funding needs. The BBC submission to the Davies committee had asked for an extra £650m a year to fund new digital services and ensure its public service remit was not watered down.

The digital licence fee proposal met with howls of protest from commercial media players, including the ITV companies and BSkyB, which said it would blight their efforts to sell digital TV services to the public.

August 2 1999: BBC executives were stunned by the defection of iconic sports presenter Des Lynam to ITV. Lynam signed a four-year deal reportedly worth £5m, citing unhappiness with the late scheduling of Match of the Day as one reason for his move.

June 24 1999: In a brief statement, the BBC announced that Dyke would replace Sir John as director-general. The announcement followed an extraordinary few days of behind-the-scenes political manoeuvring and intrigue. The final decision to appoint Dyke had been taken the previous evening by BBC chairman Sir Christopher Bland and the board of governors over dinner.

Even at this stage, the governors remained split, with only seven of the 12 believed to have joined Bland - a close friend of Dyke's since their days working together as LWT chairman and chief executive, respectively - in approving his appointment. They had failed to reach agreement the previous week, amid newspaper reports that governors opposed to Dyke's candidacy, including vice-chairwoman Baroness Young, had threatened to resign over the issue - rumours officially denied by the BBC.

The reason for the split was the controversy over Dyke's links to Labour and whether he would be impartial. Back in April, the Times had sparked a row over Dyke's political allegiences by revealing he had donated £50,000 to Labour since 1994.

Rival candidates - who included BBC News chief executive Tony Hall, ITV chief executive Richard Eyre and BBC director of television Alan Yentob - had also begun briefing against Dyke in the spring and early summer, as the odds on him landing the job shortened and the race to become BBC director-general came increasingly dirty.

Tuesday August 1
Pastor Ray McCauley, the man to whom Hansie Cronje turned when the allegations against him become known, urges him not to cash in on his downfall. "My advice to him would be to stop, stop right now ... I think that at this time ... it is important for him to be seen as somebody that is very repentant for what's happened and also that he needs to put back into the nation something other than just the fact that he's going to walk away from it."

AC Muthiah, President of the BCCI, urges the Indian government to conclude match-fixing investigations as swiftly as possible. "It is very demoralising for the team to play when you have a sword hanging over your head."

Wednesday August 2
In New Delhi, income-tax officials open the bank locker of Ajay Jadeja, one of many sealed during the nationwide raids on July 20 and July 21.

Thursday August 3
John Bacon, secretary of the King Commission, confirms that any money made by Hansie Cronje from book deals emanating from the match-fixing scandal will not be scrutinised by the commission. "We only cover the period up to April 17 this year. Anything beyond that doesn't concern us ... That's his own private affair."

Ajay Jadeja is questioned for over seven hours by income-tax officials. Afterwards he says he is innocent, and accuses the media of exaggerating the severity of the issue.

An Indian website, tehelka.com, reports that Mohammad Azharuddin and Salim Malik have paid up to £500,000 into each other's bank accounts. An unnamed tax official is quoted as saying, "Azharuddin should be behind bars for a decade ... we have proof that Mukesh Gupta paid for the Lokhandwala house of Azha ... After Hansie (Cronje) linked his name to Mukesh Gupta, Azhar went on a document burning spree. But we have still managed to get details ... If there is no political pressure we have innumerable grounds to arrest him soon."

Friday August 4
BCCI president AC Muthiah, secretary Jaywant Lele and treasurer Kishore Rungta are interviewed by CBI officials in Delhi. "This was a mutually arranged meeting ... (The CBI) asked us for balance sheets which we handed over to them. They also wanted to know how the subcommittees were appointed and how they functioned. All the details were given to them. Besides this, nothing else was discussed," Muthiah says, although the CBI deny that the meeting was mutually arranged.

Saturday August 5
Police in New Delhi arrest a third bookmaker, Sunil 'Bittoo' Dara, with alleged match-fixing links. This follows the earlier arrest of Rajesh Kalra and Kishan Kumar.

Sunday August 6
An Indian website, tehelka.com, reports that Mohammad Azharuddin and Salim Malik have paid up to £500,000 into each other's bank accounts. An unnamed tax official is quoted as saying, "Azharuddin should be behind bars for a decade...we have proof that Mukesh Gupta paid for the Lokhandwala house of Azhar...After Hansie (Cronje) linked his name to Mukesh Gupta, Azhar went on a document-burning spree. Monday August 7
In a letter to the PCB, Salim Malik pleads for the withdrawal of the lifetime ban imposed him in the Qayyum Report. "There were four specific allegations of match-fixing against me and I have been found not guilty in two of them. In the third allegation, a person could not be testified. Tuesday August 8
In India, Deputy Finance Minister Dhananjaya Kumar announces in Parliament that tax officials have seized unaccounted wealth worth $900,000 during the nationwide raids, codenamed "Operation Gentleman," conducted last month. Wednesday August 9
Greg Melick, Australian cricket's new match-fixing watch-dog, has found no reason to believe Salim Malik's claim of a double fix in 1994. "Mr Melick has conducted a comprehensive and thorough investigation into the Salim Malik claims and established that there is no evidence to support such suggestions," says ACB chief executive Malcolm Speed.

Friday August 11
The King Commission's interim report is published. It makes no recommendations for disciplinary action, although it does allow the UCB to convene a disciplinary hearing on Herschelle Gibbs, Pieter Strydom and Henry Williams. No decision has been reached as to whether Hansie Cronje was completely honest during the hearing, and thus eligible for immunity from criminal prosecution.

Charles Williams, the father of Henry, accuses match-fixing investigators of racism. "My son and Gibbs were offered money, but did not take it...How can their sporting careers be taken away from them? I know other guys in the team are guilty, but they can play. Why can't the coloureds?"

Sunday August 13
Income-tax authorities in India say that they are preparing a report on the findings of the raids on July 20/21, in which the lockers and houses of cricketers, administrators and bookmakers were searched.

Monday August 14
Shamila Batohi, the chief advocate of the King Commission, is to travel to India in an attempt to gain further evidence. Her duties include listening to the tapes held by Indian police which originally led to the Commission being established.

Wednesday August 16
On rediff.com, Leslie Sackstein, Hansie Cronje's lawyer, defends his client's "democratic right" to earn money through interviews, articles, books and films. Indian Sports Minister SS Dhindsa complains about the BCCI's attitude towards the inquiry into the match-fixing scandal. "I had some reservations against the BCCI. Thursday August 17
BCCI treasurer Kishore Rungta appears before the CBI to clarify the Board's position on a number of issues, including the match-fixing scandal.

King Commission spokesman John Bacon tells Times of India that chief prosecutor Shamila Batohi and investigator captain Geoff Edwards will spend a week in India. "We cannot yet confirm when they will be leaving South Africa...They will certainly be wanting to talk to Azharuddin and also to listen closely to the tapes in the possession of the Indian police."

Kapil Dev, the current Indian coach, says that he is considering severing his ties with cricket. "If this is what I get for being a cricketer, I do not want to be part of it. Saturday August 19
Herschelle Gibbs and Henry Williams plead guilty to accusations of accepting $15,000 from Hansie Cronje to underperform in a Nagpur one-day international in March. A three-man tribunal will decide their fate, and that of Pieter Strydom, to be announced on August 28 or 29.

Sunday August 20

Thursday August 24
The King Commission's interim report is passed to the UCB. "It is being made public on Friday. We will post it on the government's website," said spokesman Graham Abrahams. Meanwhile, R N Sawani, joint director of the CBI declares that he is "satisfied" with the progress being made in their match-fixing investigations. "In my opinion Herschelle should be given another chance to play. On the day he played superbly. Surely if you were told to get less than 20 and then you get 73 off 53 balls, then obviously you did not pay attention to what was said. You entertained the thought, you were tempted but you never followed through."

South African sports minister Ngconde Balfour confirms that there are no major surprises in the King Commission interim report, which is published on cricket.co.za. "There is not much in it really, no recommendations, nothing much. I am still of the opinion that there are only one or two people involved in this type of thing and we can easily clean up the game." The Daily Telegraph reports that Judge King has asked the South African president Thabo Mbeki to widen his terms of reference. This would allow King to investigate match-fixing dating back to 1995. Friday August 25
In his interim report, Judge King takes a dim view of Hansie Cronje*s activities. "There is a common thread to these events which is shared by others where Cronje sought to involve his team-mates in match-fixing or related matters and that is that the initial approach is made jocularly. In the second part of his interview, Cronje praises the effective work of the match-fixing enquiry in South Africa: "I think we have got to give credit to the way it is being handled here as opposed to in Australia. But I would rather have (Mark Waugh and Shane Warne*s) punishment." On rediff.com, CBI joint director R N Savani says that Kapil Dev will be summoned before the CBI shortly. "No date has been fixed for the meeting, but it will take place."

The BCCI submits a copy of its code of conduct to the Indian government. Former CBI joint director K Madavan is confirmed as Commissioner of Inquiry.

Saturday August 26
Cronje absolves Nicky Boje of any involvement in match-fixing. Boje had been mentioned in alleged telephone calls between Cronje and an Indian bookmaker.

Sunday August 27
Income-tax officials in India raid the residence of off-spinner Nikhil Chopra in connection with their match-fixing investigations.

Monday August 28
Herschelle Gibbs and Henry Williams are banned from international cricket until January 1, 2001, while Pieter Strydom is acquitted of a charge of attempting to place a bet during the 5th Test between South Africa and England. Former BCCI president IS Bindra criticises the board's treatment of Kapil Dev. "It is wrong on the part of the BCCI to gun for the team coach Kapil Dev though the board had earlier promised all help to him."

Tuesday August 29
Speculation mounts that Cronje could face civil claims running into millions of rands from past and present team-mates who suffered financial losses in the match- fixing scandal. The player also says that Cronje approached players from the traditionally less privileged sectors of South African society "to do his dirty work for him."

In the Cape Times Herman Gibbs, father of Herschelle, is quoted as deeming the sentences "bullshit - the boys have suffered enough. What I would like to know is who are the UCB accountable to in terms of their own misdemeanours when it comes to administering the game?"

Gibbs senior also tells rediff.com that he would like to sue Hansie Cronje for corrupting his son, and the UCB for failing to protect him from match-fixing. He says his son should act "like a boxer stepping back into the ring after a bad blow", and show that he is the best opener in South Africa.

Wednesday August 30
In his cricketline.com column, Allan Donald expresses his relief that Gibbs and Henry Williams did not receive a longer sentence: "Some people would say [Gibbs and Williams] deserved life bans. Neither of them actually went through with playing poorly on purpose but the fact that they even agreed to is very serious. They know now, though, that they've done wrong, and were both probably expecting suspended life bans. I'm glad the UCB wasn't too severe on them."

BCCI president AC Muthiah criticises IS Bindra, who had expressed his dissatisfaction with the board's treatment of Kapil Dev. "Bindra could have made these remarks at the Bangalore meeting. In fact it was Bindra who had vehemently said in his earlier statements that Kapil Dev had offered money to Manoj Prabhakar and everyone knows these statements had kicked off so much dust."

The Scottish actor Iain Glen arrives for our interview looking particularly mean. His hair has been dyed black, swept back and extended for a classic evil baddie look, to fit in with his role as Lara Croft's malevolent nemesis in the feature-film adaptation of the computer game Tomb Raider, in which he stars opposite Angelina Jolie. Then he goes and ruins the façade by being nice.

Glen is at that position in an actor's career where he is the first choice for a certain recognisable television role - the boyish, slightly off-kilter, but down-to-earth bloke who understands women, typified by his sports journalist in Glasgow Kiss - but not to the extent that he has been typecast, meaning that he can play a cad too. The ITV two-parter Anchor Me seems perfectly suited to his particular abilities. He plays Nathan, a Somerset boy who has educated himself out of his class, returning home to his dying mother with the hope of making his family face up to the death of a younger brother. What starts off as typical Barratt-Homes Sunday-night middle-England drama develops into a web of intrigue spun by fraught emotions, with the classic British trait of keeping up appearances at the root of all the problems.

"I was really drawn to it because it was one of those rare projects where you don't spend half of your time building bridges and subtexting things that aren't there," says Glen. "This felt more like classical writing - you reach as far into it as you possibly can. It's not about you trying to improve it, it's about you trying to meet its potential."

Glen's character is also trying to deal with a communication breakdown with his son, and a loss of excitement in marriage, on top of coming to terms with the long-buried family tragedy. On returning home he reaches back into the salad days of his childhood as all these crises loom down on him, and unfortunately finds consolation in the arms of his teenage sweetheart, now married to his rather brutish brother.

"Most television dramas are simplified to the point where you only have a simple objective to convey by a simple line, but the stuff of life is often where we're saying we're incredibly happy with something when in fact we're fiercely jealous and so on. So when writing conveys that, it's easier to play because you're immediately in a familiar situation. Underpinning the whole drama is the idea that people don't communicate, that people miscommunicate."

Another theme is the sibling rivalry between the one who escapes from the nest and the one left to fend for the family in the shadow of the more glamorous other. Surprisingly, Glen claims to be of the latter category. "As my brother so touchingly put it in his best man speech at my wedding, he didn't recognise I had a personality until I was 18, so it was hard to remember anything flattering to say about me. I always felt in his shadow - I'd like to put it down to the fact that he was four years older than me, but maybe it was just that I wasn't capable at very much. It's difficult to speak about such things without sounding pretentious, but you use this kind of experience for acting - it's broadly what you would call emotional memory."

Glen was half of the phenomenon that was last year's The Blue Room, in which he played opposite Nicole Kidman as a series of clients to her prostitute at London's tiny Donmar Warehouse theatre.

"It was great," he says of working with his leggy Australian co-star. "Within two minutes of working with her, I forgot who she was and we just got on with it. There was only two of us and we had a lot of work to do. We had to find all these various sexual couplings and not end up being Nic and Iain. Does a prostitute kiss a taxi driver differently to a politician? That sort of thing." Glen has remained friends with Kidman and her husband Tom Cruise. "Our kids are the same age," he says, understatedly. "We put them together and go off for a game of golf."

Although not on a Cruise and Kidman level of fame, Glen has reached that stage where he is sometimes mistaken for his characters. "I played a serial killer once, and had men coming up to me who had decided I was fucking hard and dangerous, and they wanted to be hard and dangerous too. When it happens I either get very mincey, or run." Recent projects could up the danger ante further. He played a cad in last year's adaptation of Wives And Daughters, and next year his diabolical villain will bring a British flavour to Tomb Raider. "It has an English setting - and I've got to be careful here because we've all signed secrecy contracts - but the director has given each of the characters a whole world. Lara's looking for mysterious elements for the good of the world, and I'm doing it to destroy. I'm enjoying it immensely. We were shooting at Battersea Power Station at night, and the whole sky was lit up, vast machines were going through the shots, smoke everywhere, multicoloured welding effects falling from the skies, and I'm thinking, what am I doing here, I'm from Scotland! But my character was making it all happen. It's a real treat."

David Elleray has called for the introduction of rugby-style sin-bins in the Premiership, which he says will slash the numbers of yellow and red cards in the English game.

Speaking on Jimmy Hill's Last Word show on Sky Sports.com TV, which is broadcast tonight, Elleray used the example of Patrick Vieira's wild reaction to his initial booking during Arsenal's recent clash with Liverpool to support his case.

Elleray said: "He was upset at the challenge and then he ran around and everyone could see that the red mist had come down. Now, if that first yellow card had actually been in the sin-bin, he would have been in the sin-bin hopefully calming down, and would have come back on in a more controlled frame of mind.

"I would like us to try the sin-bin. It works in hockey, works in rugby and I would like to see it in soccer. It would reduce the number of cards and that would be fantastic."

Elleray also said that officials were under increased pressure this season to apply the letter of the law with regard to over-excited goal celebrations. Vieira and his Arsenal team-mate Silvinho both escaped punishment for taking off their shirts during the Gunners' recent 5-3 win over Charlton.

Elleray said: "If a player completely removes his shirt it should be a yellow card. I think Stephen Lodge on Saturday used the spirit of the law, not the letter of the law. It's an example of a directive which puts great pressure on referees.

"I suspect (Vieira and Silvinho) will be reported to the FA. It's tough, particularly if players are on a yellow card."

Internet company Freeserve faces relegation from the stock market's premier league after being stalked throughout the summer by takeover speculation, with rumours of a bid from Germany's T-Online resurfacing yesterday.

The company's shares have tumbled from a year-high of 925p to 252.75p, due to growing belief that one of the first European internet IPOs will be left at the altar in the wave of consolidation sweeping the sector. These fears have pushed Freeserve to the edge of expulsion from the FTSE 100 next week, when the list has its quarterly shake-up.

A Freeserve spokesperson said: "It is up to the London Stock Exchange to comment on our role in the FTSE, but it's business as usual here."

An industry source said the collapse of T-Online's £6bn bid for Freeserve in June was due to clashes between T-Online chief executive Wolfgang Keuntje and Ron Sommer, the chief executive of parent company Deutsche Telekom. Their dispute over international strategy centred on the appropriate price for Freeserve, leading to Keuntje's resignation.

"Sommer wanted a deal at any price", the source said, "whereas Keuntje did not want to throw money away. Now that Keuntje has gone, Sommer has effectively taken control. Detlev Bushal, his replacement, is very much a Sommers man and not renowned for his independence from the boss."

Analysts say that T-online is well-positioned to become a pan-European internet portal, as it has a strong position in France and is dominant in Germany. Sommers is likely to resurrect a deal for Spain's Yacom web portal, with a Freeserve takeover guaranteeing a strong UK presence, though boardroom troubles could yet scupper both deals.

High street retailer Dixons owns 80% of Freeserve, but the prospect of low revenues from flat rate internet access fees has prompted speculation about the subsidiary's status. It also led to arguments with T-Online over the company's value, which could continue if another bid is launched.

In August, Dixons announced a deal with online gaming company gameplay.com, aiming to sell computer games through Freeserve and retail outlets. The move took observers by surprise, who interpreted it as a sign that Dixons may see the company as an important part of its future.

I can obviously get people to visit the site by telling them verbally or by displaying the address on a business card. Unscrambling attachments
I do most of my word processing in Word 7 (Microsoft Office), but run into problems whenever I open a Word document sent as an attachment by just about any one else. Very occasionally it works well, but more often than not the document opens minus all its formatting, and with pages and pages of extraneous 00000000s. I have to constantly ask people to re-send me documents saved as .rtf, but this is a real pain. Why does this happen, and is there something simple I can do to sort it out? Melanie Henwood
melanieh@email.msn.com

JS: You are using an old copy of Word, and people keep sending you files created with newer copies, which your version does not understand. This is very confusing because they all have the same extension (doc) instead of different ones (wp1, wp2 etc). The obvious solution - and the one that would make Microsoft happy - is to upgrade to Word 2000. Alternatively, you could download a copy of the free Word Viewer 97-2000 from Microsoft's website. This should read most or all the files you are sent, but won't let you do anything with them. My preferred solution is to insist that people send only plain text, so I make a point of deleting unsolicited attachments unread. This works best when your mailbox is full of press releases.

Slow Zip
I bought an Iomega Zip drive, attached by parallel port to my Toshiba Satellite 2610 laptop, because I was told at PC World this would be the answer to backing it up. However, although I can transfer files containing many scans to the Zip disk, each takes 20 minutes to open there. After some email correspondence with Iomega Help, I was told that the parallel port is not suitable for files of scanned material - just what I'd bought it for! Can you help me? Joan Zilva
JZilva@aol.com

JS: Big mistake! The Satellite 2610 has a USB serial port, so you should have bought a Zip drive with a much faster USB connection www.iomega.com. Change it if possible.

There are three common types of parallel port, and the Zip installation software always selects the slowest. According to the Readme.txt file on your Zip Tools disc, the transfer speed is 2-6MB/minute for a standard parallel port, 6-17MB/minute for a bi-directional or Enhanced Capabilities Port (ECP), and 17-22MB/minute for an Enhanced Parallel Port (EPP).

I think the 2610 has ECP (check the manual and BIOS chip setting), so use the Readme file to change the Zip set-up, if possible.

It is also worth making sure you have the latest driver from www.iomega.com/software/ drivers.html To update the driver, find the ppa3.mpd file and rename it (eg to ppa3.mpd.old). Copy the new ppa3.mpd file to C:\\Windows\ System\Iosubsys and restart your PC.

Explorer glitch
Sometimes when I open Internet Explorer 5, instead of going to the pre-set homepage (Google) I am redirected to res://C\Windows\ System\SDHOCLC.DLL. I also find that my temporary internet file disk space has been reset to zero and cannot be reset, and my internet history has been deleted. What's going on? Stephen Lafferty
stephen@slafferty.freeserve.co.uk

JS: I'm glad you asked that, even though I don't have clue, because the answer has much wider applications.

When a Windows 98 file seems to be causing a problem, you can try replacing it using the System File Checker that Microsoft has not told you about.

Go to Start|Run, type sfc and click OK. This utility will attempt to check your system files and replace damaged ones.
