When August began, the American election looked as though it would be about Clinton's trousers. But the month changed everything. Watching it unfold, I saw most parts of Bill Clinton, his inimitable charisma as well as his porous apparel, receding daily from the public mind. The election will be about the future not the past. It's the most important election in the world. It may also turn out to be the best election in the world, restoring stark left-right argument to the politics of a western democracy for the first time since the 80s.

At the start, it seemed possible that the voters were getting ready to withdraw from Al Gore, the Democratic candidate for president, the forgiveness they'd offered Clinton for the Monica calamity. During that humiliation, the public withheld the loathing which many politicians and commentators, including this one, thought would empty Clinton's remaining two years of all authority. We were wrong. But George W Bush promised Americans he would restore "dignity and respect" to the White House. It was the insistent coded mantra he offered the Republican convention. For two weeks, with Gore 12 points behind in the polls, it seemed to be working.

This would have been perverse. Was Gore to be trapped between Clinton's incorrigible frailties, on which the people took delayed revenge, and his populistic brilliance, of which the vice president, a leaden speaker and earnest policy-wonk, is in regrettably short supply? The laid-back Bush, reformed alcoholic with distant rumours of cocaine lying unrebutted on the table, had the family connections, the new-leaf repentance, the pleasing manner and the apparent experience stemming from one of the weakest governorships in the US, to take advantage of the personality contest the election might easily become.

But already it is different. The personalities will continue to matter, and the body-language is finely watched. Gore hired a ballet dancer to coach him in platform movement. Significant polling gains are attributed to the most lubricious kiss any politician ever gave his wife, uncoached, on a public platform. It's also true that both candidates know their battle is for the centre, both the political and, as it happens, the geographical, the eastern-central and middle-western states. The most startling development as August waned, though, was the clarifying of their differences.

The man responsible for this is Al Gore. He needed to change the subject, away from Clinton's aura and Bush's contentless agenda, and did so by the un-American activity of turning sharply to the left. I don't want to exaggerate this. Gore is still locked into funding from corporate America, still mute on inequality, and well outflanked by Ralph Nader running as an independent candidate. But Bush is much more uncomfortable with a turn of events that is forcing him to be specific. "Dignity and respect" have almost ceased to matter, as the details of his "compassionate conservatism" begin to be ranged against a Gore programme that shows more confidence than Clinton's ever did in the traditional Democrat constituency.

Central to Bush's programme is a massive tax cut of $1.3 trillion, geared without discrimination in favour of the rich. Gore promises less than half that, mainly with subsidies to middle-class (working-class is outside the US political vocabulary) families. A projected budget surplus of $4.6 trillion over 10 years would be used by Gore mainly to cut the debt, by Bush mainly to cut taxes and start privatising social security. But Gore would spend $400bn on health care - insurance for the low-paid, and free drugs for the elderly - Bush a quarter of that. Gore favours a huge federal spend on education: $115bn over the decade, a 50% rise in an area traditionally left to states and localities. Bush, while making education his social priority, wants to rearrange school structures rather than spend anything like that kind of money.

Whoever wins, Congress will have the final say in all this. But other differences speak as clearly for a philosophical divide. Bush and Gore would engage with the public and the Senate from starting points quite distant from each other. The most blatant contrast is over environmental protection, where Gore's commitment is as lengthy and knowledgeable as Bush's is Texas-brutish towards any measure making life harder for business, and damn the consequences for global warming. Myriad crucial choices display the same cleavage of attitude. Three seem especially noteworthy. Over gun control, national missile defence and abortion rights, the American voter has to choose between leaders who are absolutists on none of them, but whose preferred biases are heavily divergent.

Gore's predicament, in other words, has turned this into an issue-based campaign. He had to do it this way. It conformed to his own wonkish nature, and played to his strengths as a serious politician who has built national experience over 30 years. More pressingly, it was the only escape-route from the trivialities that suited Bush better. It has forced Bush into the open, requiring the sort of performance in which he has so far failed to shine.

How, exactly, the issues turn out to be argued is another matter. There's more money available for this year's campaign than for any in recorded history, and most of it will be spent on 30-second TV and radio commercials. That's the idiom that will blanket the airwaves with increasing frenzy for the next two months. America is not a predominantly political country. There is no conversation that could be called national. Many people will have little background against which to measure the roaring assaults. Reduced to three sentences, the case for a trillion dollar tax cut may be all too easily misunderstood. We're not talking Socratic dialogue here. Personal viciousness will also be heating up. It's perfectly suited to the insidious soundbite. The pretence that the other guy is sincere, a ritual bow this August to focus-group disgust at "divisiveness", will soon explode.

But those are commonplace developments: louder and richer than ever, but the usual currency of American politics. What is not usual is a disagreement that can be called ideological. That has not been so common, to put it mildly, in American as in European postwar politics. In this contest it is more explicit than in the last German, French or British elections - though William Hague is doing his best to ensure that next year's choice will be clear enough. What Gore, with the aid of Bush, is doing is to challenge some of the assumptions which persuaded Clinton that the only way he could win and govern was by leading his party from the right. This is making for an epic contest, to be decided as usual by money and organisation, but introducing the US in a new role that puts Europe to shame: leader of a political argument that really matters.

A strange thing is happening in clubland. Perhaps it is just that club design and music have been plundering their pasts for so long, that all possible variables have been exhausted. But the people who run them seem to have decided that they have only one chance left for inventiveness and individuality in terms of design: the toilet. Or, more specifically, the women's toilet.

Go to any swanky club these days and you are likely to find that what was once a rather odious, former broom cupboard equipped with cold running water and a greying sliver of soap (if you were lucky) has been expanded to lounge proportions, decorated with the opulence of a high-class bordello, and filled with more toiletries than you could decently cram into your handbag. These days, you're nobody in clubland if you haven't managed to instal a headline-grabbing loo.

We've had the great female urinal debate, in which club promoters seemed shocked to discover that women were reluctant to flash their pants in front of an assembled company of random strangers. Then there was the infamous one-way mirror in the ladies' loo at the Elbow Room in Islington, north London, where the men assumed that the reflective surface in front of them was merely a way to check their hair/flies/teeth, until they were alerted by the shrieks and bangings from the other side of the glass. Now, the Infinity club in Manchester has installed double cubicles or "twobicles" for female customers. So popular are they that the queues are enormous, even when other, single cubicles are free. "Ladies always seem to go to the toilet in pairs," says Rob Broadbent, marketing manager of the club. "What they do in there has always been something of a mystery among us men."

Ah, that old chestnut - the universal complaint of blokes who are just trying to fathom the strange and flighty creatures with whom they share their lives. I don't know who it was that first picked up on it, but I remember Jasper Carrott doing a whole routine about it in the mid-80s, along the lines of a baffled why-do-they-do-it? Did nobody think of telling him: "Jasper, we're just trying to get away from you for a bit?" And remember the scene in the film Trainspotting? Two women are - wait for it - in a club toilet. One is telling the other that she has read an article in a women's magazine about how delaying sex for five weeks is good for a relationship; meanwhile, outside, the man in question is moaning to his mate that he can't wait any longer. When the women return, the men demand, with more than a trace of paranoia: "What have you been talking about?" The women look at each other and say, in flawless unison: "Shopping."

This incident reveals men's deep-seated fear of the female toilet confab: it both fascinates and repels them. They are afraid of being discussed, but just as afraid of not being discussed.

Let's get this straight, once and for all: the female toilet is beauty parlour, counselling room, haven, bathroom, chill-out zone and lounge all rolled into one. The conversation is as likely to be about men as it is about music. Or clothes. Or who is in that night, or what is on TV, or office gossip, life laments, existential reflections - whatever.

It's not that we are going behind closed doors to bitch and scheme about the opposite sex; shooting the breeze in the privacy of a closed cubicle is just part of a night out. Women, despite their reluctance to use urinals, have fewer issues with the intimacy of bodily functions than men do: men don't even exchange eye contact in lavatories, let alone lipstick, loo paper, scandal and confidences.

It must also be considered that going in with your friend means a certain social protection when you come out: you don't want to reappear on your own to find that your friends aren't where you left them, you're now alone - and seemingly easy prey to the bar sharks that lurk in any club.

No matter how female-friendly clubs have become in recent years, you would be hard-pressed to find a woman who feels completely at ease in one on her own. There is, of course, another reason why roomy cubicles might be approved of by clubbers.

Had the Infinity management considered that their innovation might be used by people wanting to ingest illegal substances through certain orifices? "Certainly not," they said, outraged.

Eliyahu Ben Elissar, who has died aged 68, was Israel's first-ever ambassador to an Arab country. He gained his Cairo posting as a reward for heading Israel's negotiating team at the original Camp David talks of 1978, and his mere presence in Egypt's capital broke many a taboo between Arabs and the Jewish state. He then represented the Likud party for 15 years in Israel's parliament, the Knesset, before accepting the plum diplomatic assignment of Washington in 1996. In 1998, he became ambassador to France. Domestic Israeli politics had seen him ordered home, but he died within a week, in Paris.

Initially, little suggested that Elissar would make an ideal peace-broker. He was a lifelong advocate of extreme rightwing views, derived partly from his own experience as a Holocaust orphan. He condemned the Oslo accords of 1993 as "the murder of our state", but dutifully defended Israel's policies overseas.

As a teenager, he associated with Lehi - or the "Stern gang" - the most violent Jewish underground group in the Palestine of the British Mandate. The new state of Israel was very much a Labour Zionist creation, Lehi was forcibly disbanded, and in 1950 Elissar left the country. Still, the cunning and passion of zealots was not to be squandered. Mossad tracked him down to Paris, where he was studying political science and law at the Sorbonne, and recruited him as their European controller for agents operating in Arab lands.

Elissar emerged from the shadows in 1965 to serve as representative for the rightwing Herut/Likud party within the World Zionist Organisation. There he met the dynamic and personable Nitza, whom he married in 1979. By the 70s he had become a confidant of Menachem Begin, Israel's fiery opposition leader. After Likud ousted Labour in 1977, it was Ben Elissar who ran the new prime minister's office. Begin recognised in him a kindred spirit: Polish-born, suspicious and intelligent, scarred by memories of anti-Semitism and genocide; a naturally cautious man, yet willing to act boldly if required.

In November 1977, Egypt's President Sadat surprised the world by announcing his intention to visit Jerusalem. Elissar arranged the welcome for him, and suddenly faced a new crisis: finding sheet music for the Egyptian national anthem. A year later in Maryland, he agreed to return the entire Sinai Peninsula to the Arab republic in exchange for lasting peace.

Rightwingers were shocked that a Greater Israel devotee could "abandon" Jewish settlers in their desert outposts. But Elissar knew better. By jettisoning territory, Israel secured its southern flank from future attack; drove a spoke in the wheel of pan-Arab unity; and deferred more painful sacrifices demanded by Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza.

Life in Cairo tested the ambassador - it was hard to build any rapport after decades of enmity - yet he came to know Egypt's leader well, and wrote admiringly of him in a book, Sadat and his Legacy (1998).

Such future diplomatic triumph could scarcely have occurred to the boy born in Radom, central Poland, in 1932. He was just 10 when he arrived in Palestine after being smuggled out of a Nazi-controlled ghetto. His parents and siblings all perished in Europe. Elissar's recollections of the period informed his whole life: "When an enemy says he is going to kill you, believe him," he warned.

At the same time, Elissar had all the attributes for diplomatic life. He was charming, discreet, had a history doctorate from Geneva University and spoke several languages. His sartorial elegance, intellectual demeanour and neat square beard made him seem like a reincarnation of Theodor Herzl, the 19th-century founder of political Zionism.

After Cairo, Elissar served as a Likud member of the Knesset from 1981 until 1996, and twice chaired the legislature's influential foreign policy and defence committee. When his party returned to power, he accepted the ambassadorship to Washington and moved there in September 1996.

At first Elissar was hopeful: "The USA and Israel don't have to agree on everything, but we will always remain family," he said. Unfortunately, he became a pawn in a power struggle between his sponsor, foreign minister David Levy, and his prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu. "Bibi" undermined him repeatedly, excluding him from meetings with the president and contradicting him.

To make matters worse, Elissar assumed his post just as the Jerusalem tunnel crisis was erupting. US-Israeli relations hit a nadir over construction at Har Homa, when the Palestinians were not consulted about the passage excavated at the base of the Temple Mount, and violent protest resulted. The ambassador also tried to assuage American non-Orthodox Jews who felt threatened by Israel's conversion laws. He denied press rumours that he had authorised spying, and retorted that the FBI was tapping embassy phones.

Yet, overall, Elissar handled his brief with dignity, and forged valuable links with Jordanian and Pakistani diplomats, Arab-Americans and US Senators. He was relieved to be posted to Paris in 1998, where he had worked as an embassy security guard nearly 50 years earlier. Within two years, however, he fell victim to more domestic political intrigue: David Levy resigned as foreign minister, and prime minister Barak ordered his appointee, Ben Elissar, to pack his bags.

He is survived by his wife, son and daughter.

A 21-year-old football hooligan deported from Euro 2000 yesterday became the first person to receive an international ban under controversial new powers.

Christopher Sawford was served with a court summons when the Football (Disorder) Act came into force on Monday and yesterday was banned by magistrates from domestic and international games.

Sawford, a Swindon warehouse worker, must surrender his passport and report to police at the time of the kick-off of England games, starting with the friendly against France in Paris on Saturday.

Civil liberty campaigners have criticised the law as draconian because those suspected of hooliganism can be banned even if they do not have convictions. Potential suspects are identified by football information officers who help build up evidence, which can include CCTV footage and eyewitness reports.

But the Home Office said it was pleased that the police and courts were using the new powers, introduced after the government was embarrassed by the scenes of violence involving England fans during Euro 2000 - and encouraged them to continue to do so in advance of Saturday's game.

Special courts will be sitting close to ports and main railway stations so that banning orders can be imposed in the run-up to the game, though police have been playing down the chances of trouble.

Sawford was one of dozens of England fans arrested by Belgium police at Euro 2000 on June 16 and deported. Magistrates were yesterday told of his history of violence while following England and Swindon Town. He has two convictions, dating back to 1996 and 1998, for threatening behaviour at a football match.

Yesterday Sawford was banned from every domestic game in England and Wales and every England match, home or away, for two years.

He will have to surrender his passport at least five days before England play abroad and failure to do so will mean up to six months' imprisonment and a fine of up to £5,000.

Sawford was not at his family's smart semi-detached house in the suburb of Fresh brook, Swindon, last night.

His mother, Ann, insisted: "He's just been tarred with the same brush as the rest of them, even though he has done nothing wrong. He's always been a good boy and has never given us any problems."

There are several other laws already in place - such as the Football Offences and Disorder Act - which can ban fans from games as long as they have convictions for football violence. Under those laws there are currently 115 international and 474 domestic bans in place.

The campaign group Liberty has described the legislation as "ill thought out and hastily constructed" and suggested that it would be open to challenge under human rights legislation.

Scotland's discredited examination authority yesterday admitted yet another mistake in a series of embarrassing blunders that have left thousands of pupils with the wrong results.

The Scottish Qualifications Authority, which announced yesterday that two senior officials had left their posts, said that some schools had been sent the wrong information about errors made in their standard grade results.

It came a day after the SQA revealed that more than 4,000 pupils would have to have their standard grade results - the equivalent of the GCSE - re-checked because they were inaccurate or incomplete; the same setback that has already affected more than 5,000 pupils who sat the new Higher exams.

The Scottish education minister, Sam Galbraith, attacked the SQA for the latest mistake, but is himself under renewed pressure to quit over the fiasco.

"I just think the whole education system in Scotland is in a state of utter chaos," said Nicola Sturgeon, education spokeswoman for the Scottish National party. "The minister cannot stay in his post. He has absolutely no credibility. He is presiding over a chaotic situation yet he does not seem to be in control of his department."

In the latest mix-up, teachers were sent other schools' details about the pupils affected by the standard grade chaos rather than their own. The SQA blamed "sequential faxing problems" but declined to say how many schools had been involved. They said only 1% of standard grade students had received erroneous results and announced that the SQA's head of operations, Jack Greig, had been suspended pending a disciplinary investigation, and the director of awards, David Elliot, stepped down by mutual agreement.

The problems with the results for standard grade came to light when the SQA re-assessed the results of all 147,000 examination candidates in Scotland this summer after serious problems with the Higher grades. The SQA say "data handling errors" are to blame for omissions and inaccuracies in the results.

But Mr Galbraith faces pressure to shoulder responsibility for the crisis. It has emerged that the Scottish executive has blocked plans for a full debate on the issue when the Scottish parliament resumes. Instead, Mr Galbraith will give a 15 minute statement and 30 for questions.

A Scottish executive spokesman said the proper time for a debate was after the various inquiries into the affair had been completed. However, critics say the executive is ducking its responsibilities.

Lindsay Paterson, professor of education at Edinburgh University, said that was a "betrayal of accountability".

"This latest fiasco raises the question of how we are going to motivate 16-year-olds to stay at school and do their Highers ... You can't tell them the system won't fail them, because it already has."

A security scare overshadowed President Clinton's arrival in the Colombian port of Cartagena yesterday when police discovered sticks of dynamite in a flat near a building the president was due to visit.

Two men, suspected of being members of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (Farc), the country's largest guerrilla force, were arrested and anti-American leaflets seized. Colombian police said the explosives, weighing about 4.4lb, had not been made up into a bomb.

In a separate incident, security staff sealed off an area of the city after finding a suspicious device, which later turned out to be a bag of rubbish.

The visit was intended as a show of support for Colombian president Andres Pastrana's efforts to defeat the drugs trade and bring peace to the country after nearly 40 years of civil war violence.

A wave of guerrilla attacks and street protests were launched to coincide with the visit. Leftist rebels detonated a car bomb and launched attacks on police stations, army posts and banks, but most of the violence was hundreds of miles away from Cartagena, where the two presidents met to discuss anti-narcotics policy.

Around 200 Farc guerrillas launched a daylight raid on the town of Miranda in the southern state of Cauca. In a separate attack, five civilians were killed when Farc rebels rained homemade bombs on the town of Lavateca near the border with Venezuela.

The centre of Bogota was paralysed as around 2,000 students, union members and indigenous activists marched on the US embassy. Masked students skirmished with riot police and set a bus on fire.

The city was seen as too dangerous a location for talks with Colombian officials, and Mr Clinton was guarded by 5,000 Colombian troops, 350 US agents, helicopter gunships and a naval patrol boat during his visit.
