After tobacco it could be the motor industry that feels the lash of consumer activist court action, judging by a wave of safety scares to have hit Ford and other vehicle and component manufacturers.

A Californian court has ruled in favour of complaints that Ford knowingly installed defective ignition mechanisms in nearly 2m vehicles between 1983 and 1995. In a preliminary decision an Alameda county judge said he would issue an order "compelling recall and repair" of the cars which some estimate could cost Ford up to $250m.

The company says it will appeal, a spokeswoman adding: "In 18 years there has never been any evidence proving any accident or injury."

Ford chief executive Jacques Nasser has also come under fire from a US congressman for failing to appear before a House committee investigating the recall of 6.5m Firestone tyres. Shares in Japan's Bridgestone, maker of Firestone tyres in the US, hit a five-year low yesterday , affected by the investigation, calls for a wider recall of tyres and possible criminal charges in Venezuela.

Mitsubishi, Japan's fourth largest car maker in which DaimlerChrysler is buying a stake, has been downgraded by credit agencies as fears spread of the financial fallout from a customer complaints scandal which has led to more than a million cars being recalled, including some in Britain.

Potential problems

The furore led to police raids on Mitsubishi offices at the weekend, warnings about possible court action by the transport ministry and speculation that company president Katsuhiko Kawasoe could be forced to resign. The company has admitted to covering up customer complaints for more than 30 years to avoid the cost of recall.

Volkswagen of Germany said last night it was recalling 43,889 of its popular Golf model for repairs to brakes.

The level of recalls and safety scares has been growing. Last summer Ford had to recall 5,800 all-terrain Explorer vehicles because of potential problems with cruise control cables.

In spring 1999 BMW recalled 200,000 cars because of faulty radiator caps which could have filled car interiors with steam, and asked for checks on 280,000 of its 3-series cars because of an airbag fault.

Toyota recalled nearly 800,000 cars last year because of a faulty connection in the suspension which could make them almost undriveable.

But product recalls are not restricted to motor manufacturers. On Tuesday Intel, whose processors are used in 80% of personal computers worldwide, was forced to recall of its latest chip after finding it did not perform as it should. Last year the company recalled its 820 chipset due to a design fault.

None of the setbacks has proved fatal for the company involved and thecosts are relatively minor. But the impact on a brand's reputation is another matter, and that price increases exponentially if there are suggestions the company knew of a problem but tried to hush it up.

Clarence Ditlowof the Center for Auto Safety, a consumer activist group in Washington, notes that the court case in California comes at a bad time because Ford has been boasting in television commercials: "Trust us, we put safety first." According to Mr Ditlow, the court decision says of Ford: "We put profits first."

Why are these cases growing in volume? The increasing technological complexity of cars might be one factor but many industry experts are convinced that the car companies are just following a route already travelled by asbestos and tobacco groups.

Tougher government regulation and - more importantly - consumer activism put the chemical and cigarette producers into the US courts with class actions and product liability claims.

"No win no pay" offers from lawyers have encouraged millions of consumers to pursue companies through the courts. There are signs that lawyers are begining to target the motor manufacturers.

Deluge of actions

Mr Ditlow is convinced that if Ford does eventually lose the California court case it will open the floodgates to a deluge of other actions.

"Like the tobacco companies before them, car companies have had their heads in the sand. They are about to get a rude awakening."

A boy who accused a headteacher of slapping him on the face after he was refused permission to go swimming later told police there had been a plan to get her out of the school, according to a recorded police interview shown to Cardiff crown court yesterday.

Marjorie Evans is appealing against her conviction by Abergavenny magistrates for common assault, which brought her a sentence of three months' imprisonment suspended for one year. Her appeal is being funded by the National Union of Teachers, whose general secretary, Doug McAvoy, was in court yesterday for the start of the appeal hearing.

In the interview three days after the incident in September 1999, the boy, who was then 10, told police he had told his friends not to tell anyone because it would "ruin the plan". He said: "There was a plan. If I didn't tell anyone she would be out of the school. If I told anyone the plan wouldn't work. The plan was to get her out of the school."

During cross-examination by Greg Taylor, defending, via a video link yesterday, the boy, who cannot be named for legal reasons, twice got up from his chair refusing to answer questions. But he insisted that Evans had slapped him.

He said: "There was a red mark on the side of my face. It was a harder slap than I thought it would be."

Christopher Rees, prosecuting, earlier told the hearing that the boy, who has learning difficulties, became sullen after being banned from going swimming with his classmates.

It was the crown's case that Evans was faced with a difficult pupil and momentarily lost her self-control and slapped him across the face.

"The crown says it was a slap that was not administered as lawful correction, that it was not in self-defence, but that it was, plain and simply, an unlawful assault after she had lost her temper."

Evans, 56, of Usk, south Wales, told police that the boy had pushed, punched and headbutted her, but she denied slapping him.

Outside court, Mr McAvoy said he had total confidence that the appeal, before a judge and two magistrates, would result in Evans being cleared.

He said the case had damaged the image of the teaching profession and was putting off young people who wanted to teach. "Unfortunately, these sort of allegations are becoming more and more prevalent."

The case continues today.

They may not yet be in control yet, but robots have literally taken on a life of their own. According to a scientific study published today, computers can now design, test and build their own, increasingly efficient automatons, quite independently of human beings.

The breakthrough, described in the latest edition of Nature magazine, suggests that machines will ultimately be capable of "artificial evolution" - mutating, testing and improving their design far faster than living organisms.

If a "race" of computerised robots is ultimately able to reproduce itself independently - the scenario portrayed in the apocalyptic Terminator movies, starring Arnold Schwarzenegger - historians may look back to this moment as its genesis.

Hod Lipson and Jordan Pollack, computer scientists at Brandeis University in Massachusetts, acknowledge concerns about their work but argue "there are many, many further steps before this technology could become dangerous".

Earlier experiments have produced computers which could design virtual robots and put them through simulated tests, but the Brandeis scientists have gone a step further, connecting a robot-designing computer to a fully-automated machine which can rapidly build each design the software suggests.

Commenting on the experiment in Nature, Rodney Brooks, an expert in artificial intelligence at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said: "This is a long awaited and necessary step towards the ultimate dream of self-evolving machines."

Mutations

Mr Lipson and Mr Pollack gave their computer the task of developing a robot that would move along the ground as efficiently as possible. The programme responded by producing designs at random, assessing them, and then introducing small mutations to the design to discover if the changes improved the machine's speed and efficiency - imitating the natural process of evolution. "Typically, several tens of generations passed before the first movement occurred," they said.

Once the computer had "evolved" a moving robot, it tested it in the real world by sending the design to a "rapid prototyping" machine which built it from a versatile plastic. The robots emerged from the machine fully-formed apart from the motors, which had to be snapped into place by the scientists. That was the only part played by humans in the process.

The computer produced several types of robot which used different methods of motion - some moved sideways like crabs, others swung from side to side, another pulled itself along with two limbs.

"Although both the machines and the task that we describe are fairly simple compared with the products of human teams of engineers (and with the products of biological evolution) we have demonstrated a robotic 'bootstrap' process, in which automatically designed electromechanical systems have been manufactured robotically," the report says.

If left to their own devices, computers could evolve far faster than living organisms, generating mutations and testing them against the environment in seconds instead of thousands of years.

"I'm not saying a computer can replace an architect - at least not yet," Mr Pollack told the New York Times recently. "But our computer did start with a simple algorithm and end with blueprints for structures that it took humans hundreds of years to develop. And when we built the structures, they were functional."

Ultimately, he said the technology could be used to build entire factories which would turn out huge numbers of robots "as cheaply as Sony Walkmans".

The Brandeis scientists argue that to attain artificial life, machines have to gain "full autonomy", not only in their behaviour "but also at the levels of design and fabrication". "Only then can we expect synthetic creatures to sustain their own evolution," they wrote in Nature.

Ominously for anyone who has seen the Terminator films, scientists are not only programming computers with the knowledge that allows them to reproduce, they are also teaching them how to organise.

In the same edition of Nature, computer specialists at the University of Lausanne in Switzerland describe how they have taught robots community spirit, by programming them to respond to each other like ants. Based on a few simple "rules" a large group of small robots reportedly displayed "astonishing feats of organisation".

The Swiss scientists found that these insect-like "antbots" were more efficient working in groups than they were individually, and suggest that swarms of them could explore unfamiliar or hostile environments. Putting these two breakthroughs together, in theory, planets could be colonised by robots capable of infinitely reproducing themselves.

Innovations: Guards and gastrobots

 Thai scientists have just unveiled Roboguard, according to an issue of the New Scientist published today. It totes a laser-sighted gun and can track suspects via infrared sensors. It can fire at will, or it can check with a human via the internet before it attacks. So far the fire command is protected by a password.

"We think the decision to fire should always be a human decision," says Pitikhate Sooraksa of King Mongkut's Institute of Technology in Bangkok. "Otherwise it could kill people."

 A Brussels consortium is working on a full-size, autonomous walking robot dinosaur which will stroll round European museums. The creation of the automaton, based on the species Iguanadon atherfieldensis, has involved McNeill Alexander, the British expert on dinosaur biomechanics. But the robot engineers behind the project are stalking a bigger prize: a "walking" rescue machine that could step through minefields, over avalanches or collapsed buildings looking for human survivors.

 A flesh-eating robot called Chew Chew could be the first automaton to be completely powered by food.

The 12-wheeled "gastrobot" was unveiled this month in Hawaii. It uses bacteria to convert food into chemical energy.

Meat is the most efficient fuel, but a gastrobot could even mow lawns and use the clippings for fuel. A Bristol team has designed a slug-eating robot, and suggested that a fish-eating robot could monitor beaches for sharks.

 Scientists from New York and Israel have co-operated on a robot surgeon which performs human knee replacement operations. Of 200,000 knee operations in the US each year, 10% need to be done again because of surgical error. The argument is that a human-monitored robot hand would always be steadier, would work in finer detail, and never get tired. Next step: robots for surgery.

 Delaware scientists have designed Flobot the Robot. It can hover on a cushion of air and use magnetic grippers to grab a moving object while hovering over a table.

 Los Alamos scientists have built tiny little four-legged robots which have been tested on fields of unexploded ordnance. If a leg gets blown off, the robot carries on with only three, or two, or one.

 Carnegie Mellon University scientists have built Nomad, an automaton which will search for meteorites in Antarctica.

The vicious loyalist feud in Northern Ireland yesterday saw two dozen homes attacked in Carrickfergus, Co Antrim, ravaged as neighbour targeted neighbour in a night-long orgy of tit-for-tat raids.

The Ulster Defence Association and the Ulster Volunteer Force disputed who started the trouble. There were no serious injuries, but several families were left homeless.

Police were again stepping up patrols in the area, north of Belfast. Homes in nearby Greenisland were also attacked. The housing executive said last night that it was trying to rehouse 70 families forced from their homes since the feud began 13 days ago.

Attempts to find a truce between the UDA and UVF on the Shankill Road, where the dispute began, have stalled after Monday night's shooting in Coleraine, Co Londonderry. Charlene Daly, 11, is in hospital after she was hit in the back while watching television with her family.

First minister David Trimble, Ulster Unionist leader, appealed for an end to the feud. But he sounded an ambivalent note over the re-arrest of loyalist leader Johnny Adair nine days ago, calling it akin to internment without trial.

Steven Norris, the defeated Tory candidate for London mayor, found himself at odds yesterday with William Hague, weeks after being drafted into central office to improve the party's image among gay and ethnic minority voters.

In his first interview since his summer holiday, the Tory leader said he disagreed with Mr Norris's recent suggestion that gay marriages should be treated equally under the law.

Mr Norris underlined his determination to change the Tory party's homophobic image when he said over the weekend that there was "no moral barrier" to the civil registration of gay partnerships.

The former minister, who in the mayoral contest appealed to voters who had never supported the Tories, said his party needed "educating" out of anti-homosexual prejudices. Mr Norris also criticised the use of racially discriminatory language by some of his colleagues.

Mr Hague dismissed the remarks by his new vice-chairman in an interview in the Times yesterday, suggesting that Mr Norris may only be allowed to play a token role at central office. However, the Tory leader stressed that he wanted Mr Norris to continue his work improving the image of the party.

"There are still many false perceptions about the Tory party and we have to change them," Mr Hague said.

The disagreement between Mr Hague and Mr Norris came as the Tory leader kicked off his autumn political offensive by challenging the government to introduce a bill to speed up the adoption process or face one devised by the Tories.

David and Victoria Beckham yesterday abandoned their legal battle to stop biographer Andrew Morton revealing details of their private lives in his forthcoming book, entitled Posh and Becks.

Outside the high court in London, Suzanne Reeves, solicitor for Mr Morton and his publishers, Michael O'Mara Books, said the Beckhams had mounted an "extraordinarily aggressive campaign" against her clients.

"We do not believe that celebrities, particularly those who so actively court favourable publicity, should be able to seek to use the law to silence those who aim to undertake a more objective appraisal of their lives," she said.

The couple are thought to have agreed not to bring a libel or breach of confidence action over the book in exchange for the deletion of 200 words from the 60,000-word manuscript. This clears the way for publication in October, when the book will compete for sales with Mr Beckham's autobiography, My World, to be published by Hodder Headline around the same time.

The couple's lawyer, Michael Tugendhat QC, said the Beckhams had accepted legal advice on "what the law permits to be published in respect to certain passages".

The couple had objected to information given to Mr Morton by their former bodyguard, Mark Niblett, 40, who stopped working for them in May. They argued that Mr Niblett had breached a confidentiality clause in his contract.

Geoffrey Robertson QC, for Mr Morton and his publishers, told Mr Justice Evans-Lombe: "The claimants may not agree with [the book's] contents, but accept what the law allows in a society which holds fast to free speech principles."

Confidential details of the settlement were lodged with the court.

Michael O'Mara, publisher of Mr Morton's controversial biographies of Princess Diana and Kenyan president Daniel arap Moi, later said he was "thrilled" at the settlement, describing it as "a huge climb-down" on the part of the England footballer and Spice Girl.

"In the end it all came down to trifling details," he said. "This was a Robert Maxwell-type action: rich and famous people trying to control all press coverage about them through the courts."

He said the Beckhams' legal challenge had been "extremely misconceived", resulting in the deletion of around 200 words in return for invaluable press coverage of the book.

"We could not possibly have bought this much publicity," he said. "The Beckhams have probably tripled the sales and for that I thank them roundly."

Asked about the book's content, he said: "Andrew was interested in the business of celebrity and how modern celebrities use their fame. Andrew thinks this new form of celebrity is not necessarily all for the good. He wanted to write about it."

Mr O'Mara hinted that the book would centre more on Victoria Beckham than on her husband, whom he described as a "straightforward" man who likes cars and clothes.

"Unlike him she hasn't got an abundance of natural talent at something, but she's taken what she's got and made a hell of a lot more of it. In the book Andrew shows how he admires Victoria for her business skills. She is possibly one of Britain's top businesswomen."

A spokeswoman for the couple said: "David and Victoria Beckham had never planned to ban Andrew Morton's book but had wanted to stop a former employee from revealing details about their private lives.

"A sensible compromise has been reached... clarifying which matters Mr Morton and his publishers are and aren't entitled to publish."

She added: "The case against Mark Niblett continues."

A £7m advertising campaign reflecting the harrowing situations confronted by police officers was launched yesterday in a bold effort to recruit thousands into the service at a time when overall numbers are at their lowest for a decade.

The first of three TV commercials with the theme "Could you?" was due to be broadcast during peak viewing time last night, marking the first stage of a three year marketing drive masterminded by the London agency M&C Saatchi.

The first advert features the Falklands war veteran Simon Weston. "People say I'm brave. I've had to deal with a lot in my life," he says. "But to go round to somebody's house to tell a man that his wife and child have been killed by some drunken idiot in a car crash... I'm not sure I could do that."

The actress Patsy Palmer - who played Bianca Butcher in the BBC soap EastEnders - and the former England footballer John Barnes describe different challenges in two other films.

The government is hoping this first national campaign will ease the recruitment crisis facing a service which has been battered by bad publicity in recent years and is suffering from poor morale.

Although the Home Office has set aside cash to recruit 9,000 extra officers nationwide over the next three years, the increase will only be meaningful if forces can retain the staff they have.

Figures released yesterday showed the number of police officers in England and Wales had dropped from 127,158 in 1997 to 124,418 in March this year.

The Metropolitan police has warned if the haemorrhage continues, it will soon have its lowest number of officers on record.

M&C Saatchi was set the task of devising a campaign which would lift the spirits of existing officers while encouraging the right calibre of potential recruits in the key 25 to 35 age group.

Although the TV ads are hardhitting, the home secretary, Jack Straw, and Paul Whitehouse, chairman of the Association of Chief Police Officers, insisted they were not negative.

"We have to show in an honest way the challenges facing police officers," said Mr Whitehouse, who was an adviser to the agency.

"We had to get away from the type of adverts which say 'Join the police and become a chief constable in three weeks' or 'Join and drive a fast car'. If someone is put off policing by the advertisments, then they are probably not the sort of person we need."

Mr Straw said he asked the agency about the defensive tone of the commercials but was assured they had been well received in sampling, especially by the young.

He said the police needed to recruit officers who relied on brain rather than brawn. "The purpose of our campaign is simple. It is to help local forces attract recruits of the highest quality and expertise over the next three years."

The shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, yesterday said the fall in police numbers was an embarrassment for the government.

"Jack Straw can embark on all the photo opportunities he wants. There is no denying that the thin blue line has got thinner. Jack Straw promised to increase police numbers. He has failed to deliver."

Fred Broughton, chairman of the Police Federation, welcomed the campaign but said it was only a start. "More needs to be done to halt the decline in police numbers. We have been calling for extra resources to boost manpower for the last 10 years. But something is at last being done."

Where low-cost homes make hearts beat faster

"Has Heartbeat started again then?" said the recruitment office at Newby Wiske hall, where North Yorkshire police are finely tuned to the effects of the nostalgic TV series on weary Metropolitan colleagues' minds.

The quiet scrapping of a gentleman's agreement between forces not to poach serving officers from elsewhere has lent a big hand to solving manpower problems for chief constables with rural and low-cost housing beats.

North Yorkshire, which includes two national parks and a wealth of villages out of commuter range, has taken on 24 experienced officers from other forces since placing its first advertisement for transfers earlier this year. Another eight are in the pipeline, along with 45 new recruits without previous policing experience.

"It has traditionally been the case that you did not advertise for people to transfer," said a spokesman for the North Yorkshire force. "But the chief constables decided to drop their unwritten agreement and we put an advertisement in a police publication. We have lost two officers transferring out to other forces, but the balance is heavily in our direction."

The end of the "no poaching" agreement this year has started to free the internal market in police manpower, according to the Police Federation, although no change in the law or force regulations has been involved.

A spokesman said: "Officers have always applied for transfers for various reasons, particularly the cost of housing in some parts of the country, but it has not been officially encouraged until now."

The Association of Chief Police Officers said that the bar on advertising had been "understood, never written down", but chief constables had finally decided to end it.

Demand for police jobs is not entirely a matter of fine landscapes, with a largely urban force like West Yorkshire receiving 2,000 letters of interest for 60 recently advertised jobs for newrecruits.

But North Yorkshire said: "There definitely is a Heartbeat factor. An awful lot of colleagues from elsewhere want to work on the North York moors."

When the presiding judge, Lord Sutherland, granted another short adjournment to the Lockerbie trial yesterday, as defence and prosecution counsel tussled over access to CIA cables, there was clear regret in the judge's voice.

The biggest mass murder trial in British history has been beset by delays from the outset, but the current delay centres on a crucial witness whose testimony may decide whether the case against the two Libyans accused of the bombing stands or falls.

Since the Scottish court in the Netherlands reconvened last week, everyone has been awaiting the evidence of defector Abdul Majid Razkaz Salam Giaka, codenamed Puzzle Piece WF 140440 by the US witness protection scheme.

But after legal argument yesterday it became apparent the wait will be lengthened: over the next month the CIA will search its files for transcripts of its agents' dealings with Mr Giaka. When that task is completed, Mr Giaka looks set to become the crown's last - and most vital - witness in the case over the bombing of Pan Am flight 103 in December 1988, which killed 270 people.

As the trial has progressed the importance to the prosecution of the man who operated as a double agent while working at Malta's Luqa airport alongside Abdel Baset al-Megrahi and Al-Amin Khalifah Fhimah, the Libyans accused of the murders, has become increasingly apparent.

A succession of witnesses who failed to live up to expectations has heightened the crown's reliance on Mr Giaka. One witness mistook a Palestinian terrorist for a defendant in a photo line-up. A star witness, Edwin Bollier, who was intended to link the accused Libyans to the bomb's detonator, changed his story with such frequency that even the crown questioned his credibility.

"The crown have yet to lead evidence from a witness who says they saw al-Megrahi or Fhimah make the bomb, put it in a suitcase and load it on to the plane at Malta. They haven't even established - beyond the notion of a theoretical possibility - that the bomb was even put on the plane in Malta. They need Giaka to do that," said Robert Black QC, the Edinburgh law professor who first proposed holding the trial in the Netherlands.

But there is growing concern that Mr Giaka's testimony will not live up to that promised as far back as 1991.

Initially, Mr Giaka was expected to give evidence by the middle of last week. It became obvious last Tuesday, however, that there would be delays.

At the start of June, the prosecution met CIA officials in the US embassy in the Hague and had first sight of the unedited cables. Those present guaranteed not to make notes or disclose any of the information in the cables. The defence was given no such access: they saw only transcripts with large areas blacked out by the pen of an American censor.

Then, at the start of last week, the defence discovered the discrepancy. Under the European convention on human rights, already incorporated into Scots law, the defence and prosecution must have equality of arms. The defence counsel, Richard Keen QC and William Taylor QC, demanded unedited versions of the cables.

The lord advocate, Colin Boyd QC, said the blacked out sections were of no relevance to the defence and could not be revealed without endangering America's national security. The judges disagreed and told Mr Boyd to approach the CIA and ask for unedited version of the cables to be made available to the defence.

"The defence couldn't realistically cross examine Giaka without seeing what his CIA handlers had to say about him. This is vitally important stuff," said Prof Black.

In an unprecedented step, the CIA agreed to release the cables. By Friday, Mr Keen, counsel for Fhimah, had made a first assessment of them. He told the court the idea they did not impinge on his client's defence was inconceivable.

On Monday, as classified US intelligence documents were produced for the first time in a foreign court, the relevance of the cables was becoming apparent. One of the names in a cable was a pseudonym for a defence witness. They contained details of payments that could be given to Mr Giaka in return for giving evidence. Mr Taylor, counsel for al-Megrahi, asked for an adjournment to consider his client's defence.

As the court reconvened on Tuesday, defence lawyers demanded that all classified American intelligence documents relating to Mr Giaka be passed to the court. Lord Sutherland rejected a defence request that the court ask the US attorney general, Janet Reno, to appoint a federal judge to examine all the CIA documents and make available everything that was not a threat to national security. But Mr Boyd was told to go back to the CIA and ask directly for the documents.

Yesterday, the CIA agreed to search its files for documents concerning Mr Giaka. Again, it will take the unusual step of making public intelligence information on the Libyan's status as a double agent - and, crucially, the groups and individuals the defence claims are responsible for the bombing.

Meanwhile, further details about Mr Giaka emerged. Under codename P1, he was paid $1,000 a month for information by American intelligence agents. However, the CIA threatened to stop payment in September 1989, nine months after the Lockerbie bombing, unless he came up with better information about JSO, the Libyan intelligence service.

Before he even takes to the stand, such information - coupled with his eligibility for a $4m (about £2.75m) reward on conviction of the two accused - threatens to undermine Mr Giaka's credibility.

Legal sources are beginning to wonder to what extent he will directly link the accused to the bombing. In the late 1980s, Mr Giaka worked for Libyan Arab Airways alongside the accused at Luqa airport. He admits to being a member of Libyan intelligence services; al-Megrahi and Fhimah are accused of being Libyan spies. After he defected to the US in July 1991, he gave testimony to the FBI which formed a key part of the indictment issued in November of that year. He went into hiding. In the years that have passed he is said to have become increasingly paranoid.

When defence solicitors went to take a precognition (witness statement) before the trial, he insisted they were blindfolded. Mr Giaka wore make-up and a Shirley Bassey wig. It is understood the solicitors came away lacking the confidence in Mr Giaka which the prosecution must have in court.

But the testimony he gives -in a disguised voice, behind screens - will be pivotal. "His evidence is absolutely vital," said a legal source. "If he fails to directly blame the Libyans, at the very least the defence will claim no case to answer and the whole thing could end much sooner than anyone expected."

Partners in City of London law firms earn more than £1m a year, according to a survey of lawyers' incomes. The highest earning pocket £1.2m, according to this month's Commercial Lawyer magazine.

Leading stockbrokers, investment bankers and barristers earn more - up to £2m - but stockbrokers' and bankers' pay packets are inflated by bonuses.

Leaving aside bonuses, which are unpredictable, partners in big City law firms rake in the highest of a range of professions.

They average £708,000, more even than the average £643,000 for chief executives of FTSE 100 companies, though share options give chief executives a bigger overall package.

Without their bonuses, stockbrokers and investment bankers average £525,000 and £413,000.

Commercial Lawyer concludes that City solicitors' pay is justified by the pressures of the job - "long, intense hours, personal sacrifices and demanding expectations".

 If you had £250,000 going spare, should you blow it on a new Corniche? That is the question we address today, as we review the car so bravely lent us by Rolls-Royce and events ensuing after Gerald Kaufman, Richard Adams and myself arrived on Friday morning at Crewe.

Our museum tour guide and tutor on the car's controls, former machinist John Spragg, mentioned visits from Nigel Mansell ("lovely man, fascinating, and hilarious") and Mike Tyson ("lovely man, very knowledgable about our history"). Beginning the journey to Leeds, all three of us admiring the plushness of the sheepskin carpets and the 76 buttons to move the seats, and it was not until 33 minutes had elapsed that a Beatles tape (the Red Album) became stuck ... and, in trying to fix it, I yanked off the front of the cassette player.

 "Baby you can drive my car," as John Lennon puts it on that album, "Yes, I'm gonna be a star." Well no, I'm not. You're not going to be a star of motoring journalism, are you, if on level seven of Leeds' Schofield NCP car park you drive an automatic Corniche into a wall. Still, in a certain light (candle) you'd barely notice.

 The thing about driving a navy blue open-top Corniche with cream leather interior through areas of urban deprivation is that you do get noticed. Yet there was little hostility ... just the one "wanker" hand gesture. "What has happened to the class envy that made Britain what it was?" mused Richard. What happened to tall poppy syndrome?

 Gerald Kaufman loved the airy boot, I enjoyed the superb suspension and the smoothness of the seven litre engine, and Richard was struck by the speed of cigar lighter. "Isn't it amazing, what they can do these days for £250,000?" he said. However, he was upset by the lack of a cigar compartment light.

 To Stephen Corley who wrote of seeing RR1 "on the hard shoulder of the M1 with hazard lights flashing" late on Friday, what happened was this. For some reason, John Spragg omitted from his "cockpit drill" any warning against selecting reverse at nearly 90mph. The car snatched up sharply and lost all power, and "check gearbox" flashed up. A lovely moment. We rested on the hard shoulder, nervily restarted the car, went into drive and drew away. What a car to recover so quickly.

 The real question for anyone with £250,000, then, is have you got the nerve? I haven't. Although the car survived a night in Shepherds Bush, the next morning it went to a gentler suburb until they came to collect it on Tuesday - by which point the Spirit of Ecstasy emblem was stuck in the retracted position and the alarm system had broken. A quiet weekend, then, for RR1. As for the Diary, its career as a car reviewer ends at this apex. Richard is now working on borrowing a yacht.

The home secretary Jack Straw is considering new powers to tackle the rising violence by animal rights extremists who target the scientific community, it was confirmed yesterday.

Mr Straw is planning a full review of police powers to combat what he described as the"preposterous" and "terrible" activities of some extremists.

Scientists who met Home Office officials last month called for urgent action to clamp down on the violence against the homes and property of scientists and major shareholders in laboratories using animal testing.

Mr Straw said police were also calling for more powers to curtail protesters' activities after police figures showed 1,200 reports of animal rights attacks last year alone, causing an estimated £2.6m damage to property. But animal rights campaigners said criminal laws were already in place to deal with violent protesters.

Mr Straw told Radio 4's Today programme: "We are looking at whether there are changes in legislation that we can take which are being sought by the police to see whether we can strengthen action against these animal rights extremists.

"It is worth bearing in mind that many of us would not be able to lead healthy lives were it not for the pharmaceutical companies being able to test their drugs on animals."

The announcement follows a spate of violence against laboratory staff, culminating in the explosion on Monday of petrol bombs under five cars belonging to employees of Huntingdon Life Sciences, a research centre in Cambridgeshire.

No shrinking violet

At one of the Edinburgh Television Festival's more heated debates, Dr Raj Persaud, a consultant psychiatrist who once stood in for an ailing Esther Rantzen, warned of the possible psychological damage facing the Big Brother contestants.

"It's like putting an alcoholic on a drinking game show", he said. "These people are obsessed with becoming famous and so are not making decisions that are in their own best interests."

While no one would underestimate the agonies of the Big Brother victims as they resign themselves to a lifetime of showering in private, there must surely be more immediate concern for the well-being of Persaud, a man whose enthusiasm for the public eye makes the game show exhibitionists look like so many shrinking Miss Havishams.

For some time many of us have been worried that Persaud does not always make decisions that are in his best interests.

Should this bright young winner of the Royal College of Psychiatrists' research prize and medal really be squandering quite so much of his talent on Richard and Judy's Good Morning show, where he is the "resident psychiatrist"?

Does the author of a paper called "Psychiatrists suffer from stigma too" help his profession by writing multiple-choice How to Know Yourself quizzes for the Telegraph, by contributing features to every national broadsheet and by broadcasting, what seems incessantly, on Radio 4 - speaking of which, don't miss his next contribution, the Science of Humour (trailed in a half-page feature he wrote for last Tuesday's Daily Telegraph).

Nor should we forget his regular column in Cosmopolitan, his contributions to Men's Health magazine and his - well, anyone interested in exploring the extremity of Persaud's love affair with the media would do best to check out the biography on his internet home page, in which he lists his contributions and includes a few of the choicer compliments to have come his way since he first began to entertain us, back in the early 90s: "The Independent on Sunday said he was 'The undisputed king of the media shrink pack' and the Spectator in 1998 asserted he is 'the most eminent psychiatrist of the age... he is the guru of common sense.'"

Whether through this very abundance of common sense or through lack of space, the king of the shrinks' website does not mention his sideline as a media quotesman for all occasions, nor does he begin to itemise his numerous contributions to tabloid newspapers, in particular the Sunday People, with which he seems to have some sort of special relationship.

Not long ago he provided psychiatric input for a piece which asked (re Neil Morrissey) "Why do girls fall for men behaving badly?" "Many women put up with men behaving badly because they love the rollercoaster ride of emotion," explained Persaud. "There is never a dull moment. And when he does give his lover attention she feels more euphoric than if he had been eating out of her hand from the start."

To his credit, the doctor appears to be in control of his former habit of analysing celebrities he had never met, but there is no room for complacency: weeks ago he could not resist offering the Sun his thoughts on the perils (re Robbie Williams) of celebrity dating: "Celebrities have difficulty maintaining relationships with each other because they are always very busy, jetting all over the world and so on."

More worrying than this idiosyncratic application of his skills, however, is the emergence of certain inconsistencies in Persaud's clinical thinking. Earlier this year the Independent asked for his views on the sitcom psychiatrist Frasier. Persaud was damning: "Frasier doesn't ask the questions that we would ask, and he doesn't get the proper background to make an accurate prognosis." Which is not what he told the Mirror about Frasier in 1997: "I used to do a regular phone-in slot on a radio station and identify with him."

Which Persaud is the true one? The one who identifies with Frasier, or the one who does not? The ubiquitous showman or the earnest clinician? The contributor to Schizophrenia Research or the Cosmo agony uncle?

When the Big Brother show comes to an end the producers should not repine: all they need do is replace their 10 contestants with Persaud and let his multiple personalities fight it out.

With this chocolate flake, I thee wed

From Max Clifford to the Sun, from Garry Bushell to the president of Family and Youth Concern, the forces of righteousness unite in horror over the Bovey-Turner nuptials. Not, as might once have happened, because the groom abandoned his three small daughters for love of the refulgent former lottery show presenter, but because the institution of marriage is thought to have been tainted by the presence of confectionery.

Although it is unappealing, the degree of outrage seems disproportionate. Are the happy pair not looking forward to a future of shared mastication?

Moreover, given that they had already auctioned their intimacy, Mr and Mrs Anthea Snowflake - and their many Hello! and OK! predecessors - seem to have shown unusual restraint. Any celebrity couple wanting to make the most of this special promotional day will naturally want to exploit every one of its marketing opportunities. What is a wedding dress, for example, if not a gigantic empty hoarding, with space for 1,000 times the number of logos that conventionally adorn the suits of formula one drivers? In future the Snowflakes may come to feel they sold away their wedding rights for something less than a mess of pottage, to wit: two crumbly white flakes covered in milk chocolate, each containing 200 calories, 2.7g protein, 22.2g. carbohydrate and 11.4g fat.

Paedologists beware

No sooner had David Blunkett announced his national spelling bee, than the behaviour of vandals in Newport suggested that knowing how to place letters in the correct sequence might not in itself be enough. Not long ago, the oafs who forced a woman paediatrician from her home, believing her to be a pervert, probably had as much difficulty with spelling paedophile as they would have done with the more commonplace accommodation, or millennium or desperate.

Now - thanks, no doubt to the News of the World - they have memorised the correct spelling of "paedo", without grasping that other words beginning with the same prefix might mean something different. Happily, not too many other words start this way, though paedologists in the Newport area should be on their guard. Ditto peddlers and podiatrists. And anyone trying to make a living by letting out those charming little pleasure boats called pedalos might like to consider switching to punts.

If Rebekah Wade is interested in making amends this might be a good time to feature a little etymology item in her paper, for readers who wish to persecute sex offenders but lack the required literacy.

A wry smile plays across the face of the fair-haired young man as he explains his feelings about asylum-seekers. "When refugees are no longer in need they should go home but they don't and that's the problem. About 6,000 come here every year and if they bring their families that can add up to as many as 16,000 people."

Such views have struck a chord with many in Austria and eastern Germany but this is Denmark, a country whose liberal tolerant society has long been the envy of the world. But things are starting to change. The young man is Carl Christian Ebbesen, a board member of the ultra-nationalist Danish People's party (DPP) whose popularity ratings were as high as 15% earlier this year. The DPP's staunch opposition to Denmark ditching the krone in favour of the euro in next month's referendum has done wonders for its image and won it new-found respectability.

Its leader, the 53-year-old self-styled housewife Pia Kjaersgaard revelled in a public one-on-one debate with the Danish prime minister, Poul Nyrup Rasmussen, on the euro last week. An elfin-like blonde lady and mother of two, she does not look like a demagogue. But appearances can be deceiving and the core policies of the DPP or the Dansk Folkeparti as it is known in Danish are far from respectable.

If it ever does win power, Denmark's reputation as a liberal society would be shattered forever. Aid to the third world would be privatised and poor countries forced to take action to "restrict population growth" if they wanted to receive any help. Recidivist paedophiles would find themselves forced to undergo "medical castration" and the criteria for Danish citizenship would be severely tightened.

Refugees should, the DPP argues, be repatriated to their country of origin and only small numbers provisionally accepted. "Denmark is not a country intended for immigration and the Danish People's party disagrees with the statement that Denmark will develop into a multi-ethnic society," the party's programme reads.

The party is also hostile to the EU and would like to see the European Parliament, where it has one MEP, abolished.

Just 4.5% of Denmark's population of 5.3 million is made up of immigrants but the DPP has shown itself adept at whipping up popular anti-EU and anti-foreigner sentiment.

In 1998 Pia Kjaersgaard urged Danes to rally at Denmark's border with Germany and protest at cooperation between Jutland and Germany's Schleswig Holstein region. According to Bendt Bendtsen, the leader of the Danish Conservative party, the "cooperation" involved only minor activities such as student exchanges and a joint ambulance service. It was portrayed, however, "as a joint EU-German attempt to regain control over old German territory in Denmark."

Mr Bendtsen adds: "It was tasteless, but by playing this tune on nationalistic strings they have distorted public discussion in Denmark to a point where a real dialogue is no longer possible."

Former EU commissioner Ritt Bjerregaard warned last week that if Danes say 'nej' to the euro next month it will be seen as a swing to the DPP. Earlier this month even Jörg Haider's Freedom party refused to meet with Kjaersgaard.

Yet the DPP is a real political force in Denmark. It polled 7.4% of the vote in the last parliamentary elections in 1998 and has 13 MPs in the Folketing (parliament). Now suggestions are growing that it may soon be in a strong enough position to prop up a centre-right government in exchange for a slice of power.

Sweeping new controls on information, including details of a proposed new European paramilitary police force, have been ratified by EU governments.

The new EU secrecy code was agreed earlier this month by "written procedure", preventing any debate by the European parliament. It became part of EU law on August 23.

The code was drawn up in secret by the EU security supremo, Javier Solana, who is also secretary-general of the EU council of ministers, in cooperation with his successor as Nato secretary-general, Lord Roberston.

The controls were rushed through despite opposition from the European ombudsman, Jacob Soderman, who warned this week that the code could be applied to policy areas presently open to public scrutiny.

When Tony Bunyan, editor of Statewatch, the British-based civil liberties bulletin, asked in July for details of the Solana plan, he was told by a senior EU council official that the release of such information "could fuel public discussion on this subject".

Under the Solana plan, all classified documents relating to "security and defence of the union or one or more of its member states", or to "military or non-military crisis management", will be permanently excluded from public scrutiny.

The blanket secrecy rules will cover proposals to set up a 5,000-strong EU paramilitary police force as well as plans for a rapid reaction force. They could cover all EU discussions on criminal justice, border controls and trade policy.

The code will also enable Nato and non-EU governments to veto the disclosure of EU documents.

Documents passed to State watch show that the plans go much much further than purely military operations.

The commission says the proposed rapid reaction force could be used to quell "growing violence destabilising law and order, breaches of the peace, outbreaks of fighting, armed conflicts" and "massive population movements".

Documents which would have been suppressed under the new controls include minutes of a meeting of paramilitary police from Spain, Portugal, France and Italy in January at which they discussed the creation of a "European security and investigation force" as a "tool" at the disposal of the EU and Nato.

Paramilitary police forces, they say, are particularly qualified for the "restoration of public security", providing capabilities for "intelligence, general surveillance, judicial police [and] maintaining order".

Three young neo-Nazis were yesterday convicted of a vicious race murder, in a case that has brought to a head the German government's concern over the far right's activities in the east of the country.

The widow of their victim, Mozambique-born Alberto Adriano, stayed away from the hearing at a court in the eastern city of Halle after receiving a death threat.

The court sentenced Enrico Hilprecht, 24, to the maximum of life in prison. His two 16-year-old co-defendants, Christian Richter and Frank Miethbauer, were each given nine years in jail, one year less than the maximum sentence for juveniles.

The judge called the deadly assault on June 11 "the latest in a long chain of attacks to which we must put an end".

Germany's chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, called yesterday for the speedy imposition of a ban on the radical far-right National Democratic party of Germany (NPD). The government has moved gradually towards supporting a ban, despite the misgivings of its interior minister, Otto Schily.

Critics, including senior officials in the counter-intelligence service, have argued that such a ban would merely make surveillance of the neo-Nazi scene more difficult.

Mr Schröder will today lay a wreath at a memorial erected at the spot where Adriano was attacked so savagely that he later died of his wounds. The killing was the third this year alleged to have been carried out by members of the far right.

The court was told that the younger defendants had previous convictions for daubing swastikas.

Tolerance of neo-Nazi violence is widespread in eastern Germany, especially among the young. In an effort to end this tolerance, the chancellor yesterday appealed to east Germans' pride in their recent history, encouraging them to take a stand like the one that put an end to communist rule in 1989.

He said Germany needed a "repeat of what people in the east of our country recognised in the peaceful revolution 10 years ago", adding that the easterners had to "involve themselves and fight for the right thing".

In Dessau, where Adriano was killed, police said his German-born widow had received a threatening letter which the public prosecutor's office was investigating. A spokesman for a foreigners' rights group said she had decided not to attend the final session of the court because she was "simply too scared because of her children".

Mr Adriano, who was 39 and worked in a meat packing plant, left behind him three children, of whom the youngest is six months old.

His killers yesterday sat expressionless in court yesterday as the verdict was read out.

The defence had pleaded for shorter jail terms and for manslaughter or deadly assault charges, saying prosecutors had failed to prove that the attackers intended to kill Adriano when they set on him in a park after a drunken rampage through the city.

A defence lawyer, Sabine Grunow, said all of the accused expressed regret in brief closing statements at the end of the four-day trial. Hearings were closed to the public because of German law regarding juveniles.

Adriano was walking home in the early hours of the morning, when the three attacked him, screaming racist abuse. When they had kicked him unconscious, they stripped him of his clothes as a final humiliation.

In a further instance of racist violence, prosecutors in the northern town of Lübeck said they had arrested two skinheads for attacking and injuring a 33-year-old African man whom they had taunted with racial slurs.

Police in the German town of Waiblingen detained two men after two foreigners were slightly injured in an early-morning arson attack on a home for asylum seekers.

Late on Tuesday, a 21-year-old German man was given a five-month suspended sentence and fined 500DM (£160) for punching a Hong Kong-born photojournalist who was trying to cover racism in the east.

The French are unconcerned about the British influx into their rural midst - half a million according to Abbey National - but second home buying within the United Kingdom itself is controversial. Particularly in north Wales, some parts of Scotland, the Lake District and Cornwall, where up to a third of local dwellings are owned by seasonal visitors.

The 1990 census said England and Wales had 92,000 second homes. A more realistic estimate is closer to 250,000. They are concentrated in, for example, Wales. Some 13% of all second homes in England and Wales are in Wales, which has only 6% of all dwellings, as the chart shows. That translates into between 26,000 and 32,000 properties owned and used by "non-residents".

This causes problems not faced elsewhere in Europe. Within the UK, second home ownership evokes questions of social equality, social rights and justice. On the continent these are rarely associated with the second home phenomenon, even where concentrations of non-resident owners are heaviest. While 3% of households in the UK have second homes, figures elsewhere are consistently above 4 or 5%. In Denmark, more than 10% of households have a second home, while in Sweden, the figure is closer to 25%. But there, population densities are lower and the amount of available housing is generally higher. Scandinavian second homes are regarded in much the same way as a second car.

There are housing markets where incomers and locals compete, for example the Swedish west coast - though the issue in Sweden has more to do with the cultural shock of a sudden wave of foreign (German) buyers coming into the domestic property market.

In the UK low rural wages may make housing unaffordable. More affluent incomers out-bid locals. This means, so the argument goes, that second homes damage communities. Locals are displaced and the seasonal nature of the new population means that villages become ghost communities: village shop, post office and pub become redundant. In parts of Wales, displacement is viewed as a threat to Welsh, making the issue all the more emotive.

The ghost community notion possesses intrinsic political appeal. But in Wales as elsewhere, those on low incomes compete for housing against affluent locals, retirement migrants, commuters and teleworkers and it is often difficult to isolate the impact of second homes. Similarly, the assumption gets made that young people do wish to remain in rural communities, in spite of a lack of jobs, services and educational opportunities. There is an idea, too, that people have a natural right to live and own property in a particular place.

Second homes may contribute to a general lifting of house prices. But they may also signal continued investment in rural communities in the face of economic decline.

In Wales pressure to restrict second home buying has been building for 30 years. In the late 60s and early 70s, summer homes and static caravans became a focus for ranting and arson. By the 80s, the issue had reached the mainstream agenda. Today, the machinery which might offer greater control over second homes seems to be in place in the form of the national assembly for Wales.

Rumours that the assembly might be considering giving councils such powers was interpreted by some as a move to keep out the English. In fact, the assembly had merely raised concern over the effects of second homes in rural and coastal tourist areas. Its task force, looking at rural housing issues, has advocated research into questions of market access, stock condition and affordability rather than changing planning law.

The point, though, is that such powers are now available in Wales. In future, the assembly might be able to amend secondary legislation to distinguish between first and secondary residences. As of now they have no identity in planning law, meaning that a user is free to live in a residential property permanently or simply use it during odd weekends in the summer. Reform might involve making a distinction, as in Denmark.

Twenty years ago, people frequently used their second homes for seasonal and recreational purposes. Today, a great many more make use of modern technology and choose to work from their second home, blurring the distinction between principal and seasonal residence. For employment purposes these days (for a few), geography may not matter.

However the political arguments go, it is worth saying that second homes usually make an insignificant impact compared to commuters or retirement migrants. The bigger challenges facing rural areas relate to economic competitiveness and job creation. There must be a clear onus on local authorities to demonstrate that it is second homes rather than other types of buyers or economic issues that are causing the disadvantage experienced by locals. Second homes in other words are less significant than the social processes leading more people to work from home, commute over longer distances, or retire earlier.

Perhaps something needs to be done to aid those communities where younger residents have difficulty finding homes. But this assistance should not just focus on housing. They need answers on the economic and school fronts and on services that will encourage those who wish to remain in the countryside to stay.

Nick Gallent is at University College London; Mark Tewdwr-Jones at the University of Aberdeen. Their book, Rural Second Homes in Europe, is published by Ashgate

John Mullan admits (Law of the letter, August 30) that Dr Johnson's dictionary destroyed the previous free choice in English spellings, yet he makes the common mistake of assuming that it is only laziness or bad teaching which are responsible for difficulties with spelling.

The underlying assumption is also that an ability to spell denotes absolute intelligence, when it is actually the result of good visual memory - whether innate or trained. Indeed, "intelligence" itself is not an absolute, but is constructed from various facilities.

Logic, numerical ease, spatial intelligence, visual recall, aural memory - all are parts of intelligence, but most of us do not possess all of them together. If David Blunkett demanded that all children should be able to draw 200 artefacts and creatures by a certain age, we would recoil, because we accept that drawing is something people can or cannot do. Spelling, however, has acquired a social status harking back to the superiority of the educated classes.

Attempting to teach the chaotic and unruly spelling of English in an age when so many children's visual memories are more in contact with screens than with the letters on a page, is not an enviable task. I've done it, and believe me, it is nothing to sneer at.

Tony Vinicombe
Shoreham, W Sussex ViniView@aol.com

President Bill Clinton flew into Colombia yesterday amid a countrywide outbreak of rebel violence and protests against a massive boost in US military aid to the government.

Leftwing guerrillas attacked police stations and army posts, bombs exploded outside banks and masked students clashed with riot police.

The violence took place mostly around the three main cities and in rural areas hundreds of miles from Cartagena, the Caribbean tourist resort where 5,000 troops, 350 US agents, helicopter gunships and an American aircraft carrier provided security for Mr Clinton's nine-hour visit.

On Tuesday night, rebels attacked 12 police stations in six of the country's 32 departments. Five civilians, including two children, died when guerrillas of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (Farc) rained mortar bombs on a police station in the village of La Bateca, near the border with Venezuela.

In south-west Cali, the second largest city, Farc guerrillas detonated bombs outside three banks, causing widespread damage but no injuries, police said.

In the north-eastern oil- producing province of Arauca, another Farc unit attacked an army barracks near the town of Fortul on Tuesday afternoon, injuring six soldiers, an army spokeswoman said. Guerrillas also attacked an army post in the nearby town of Saravena. US-made Blackhawk helicopters flew to the region to strike back at the rebel column.

Rebel commanders have denounced the US aid package, which includes 60 helicopters, equipment and training for the Colombian army, saying that money will cause an escalation in the civil war, and eventually US-backed military action against the guerrillas.

"Clinton isn't here to support social investment but a military plan. We don't want to make threats, but the Colombian people have the rights to take to the streets and protest against this visit," the Farc commander, Andres Paris, told the Guardian.

In a videotaped address to the Colombian people broadcast on Tuesday night, Mr Clinton stressed the social development programmes included in the aid package, and denied that Washington planned military intervention.

"We have no military objective. We do not believe your conflict has a military solution. We support the peace process. Our approach is both pro-peace and anti-drug," Mr Clinton said.

Yesterday the Miami Herald reported that the Pentagon is planning to send an army general to oversee the military element of the aid package.

According to US law, a maximum of 500 American troops and 300 civilian contractors may be in Colombia at any time, but the president may waive the limit in the event of an "imminent involvement" of US forces in hostilities.

The largest chunk of American money will pay for 60 helicopters to support a military offensive in the rebel-dominated jungles of southern Colombia, where most of the world's cocaine is produced. The helicopters and three US-trained anti-narcotics army battalions will lead the advance, securing control of drug plantations to allow the police to eradicate illegal crops.

Mr Clinton waived strict human rights conditions to approve the aid last week, despite fears that the Colombian military maintains close ties with illegal rightwing paramilitary groups.

In its 1999 report, the state department reported "credible allegations of co-operation with paramiltary groups, including both silent support and direct collaboration."

Monitoring groups in Colombia fear that the American money will exacerbate the country's 35-year civil war and cause up to 200,000 people to flee their homes.

The largest edible crabs in the world, growing to one and a half metres across, have invaded northern Norway from Russia and spawned a new and valuable fishing industry.

King crabs as they are known, hundreds of thousands of them, are marching west along the Barents Sea and heading south towards the rest of Europe.

To the fishermen of northern Norway they are both a boon and a menace. The bonus comes because they are worth £150 each at Oslo fishmongers. The problem is that there are so many juvenile crabs - too small to eat - that hundreds of them are caught at a time and they weigh down and break the nets of trawlers. Often cod fishermen catch more crabs than fish.

The crabs originally came from the Kamchatka peninsula on the extreme eastern side of Russia, in cold Arctic waters. In an experiment in the 1960s a Russian scientist, without consulting the Norwegians, introduced them into a fjord in the Barents Sea. The area is so cold that there are no native crabs there, but the king crabs found it a home from home and thrived.

The first the Norwegians knew about them was in 1980, when a few were caught in cod nets. A huge colony has now established itself in Varanger fjord, the biggest in Norway, which is renowned for its cod and haddock. The crabs there regularly reach 1.5 metres (five feet) across - bigger than in their native waters in Asia.

The crabs have already marched 600 miles (1,000 kilometres) west of Varanger, round the coast to Tromso, and have now turned south.

The Russians and Norwegians, who share all fish catches in the Barents Sea, realise that they have a new resource with valuable export potential to Japan and the US, and are being careful not to over-exploit it.

Russia and Norway have limited their catch this year to 37,500 king crabs each, but next year, as the numbers continue to balloon, it will be larger. The Japanese are already so keen on the new fishery that they are flying special teams over to buy up the pick of the catch.

Runar Hartvigsen, regional director of fisheries and aquaculture for Finnmark, said: "This is very good news for us. Research so far shows that the king crab has occupied a niche that no other species uses, and so there is plenty of food for them but no harm done.

"The only problem is that there are so many of them, and they weigh so much, they can break the nets of our other fishermen.

"There is no way we can control the crabs' advance or their numbers; what we have to do is make the most of the business opportunity they offer."

He said that Japanese teams had already flown to Norway to investigate the fishery and planned to be there from October to January, buying the better flavoured male crabs and flying them back live to the Tokyo fish market.

Fishermen currently get £4 a kilogram (2.2lb) for the crabs at the quayside, but the retail price in Oslo is £30 a kilo. The legs are so big they are broken off, cooked in their shells and sold in restaurants as "crab sausages". "They taste superb, a mixture between prawn and lobster," he said.

The Norwegians are now experimenting with farming the crabs, anticipating potential markets in the EU.

Using medium-sized male king crabs about five years old, caught in fishing nets in March, the crab farmers are keeping them in enclosures on the sea bed and feeding them until the harvesting season begins in October. During that time the crabs will shed their outer shells and, in the two months before the new shell hardens, they will grow by 25% in size and weight.

"This means a four kilo crab in March is five kilos in the autumn, adding £20 to its value and making farming a viable proposition," Mr Hartvigsen said.

So far there appears to be no limit to the crabs' advance and scientists believe that they may reach as far south as Bergen in 10 years. By then Mr Hartvigsen believes, even the mighty king crab may slow down.

"The water south of Bergen is warmer. The king crab likes to be really cold, so it may stop advancing further south. But the fact is we do not really know until it gets there."
